questions.text: Dr. Priya is conducting a talk on the screening of cervical cancer with a Pap smear. She works in a clinic in a low-resource setting, and she was planning to screen a woman in her 20s. Which of the following is true regarding cervical cancer screening guidelines in her workplace?

choices.text: Co-testing (pap and Hr HPV) every 5 years starting at 25 years
Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 years
Hr HPV testing every 5 years starting at 30 years
Pap smear every 5 years starting at 21 years

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 years

Explanation:

Cervical cancer screening guidelines recommend starting a pap smear at age 21 and repeating it every 3 years in a low-resource setting.

 

ACOG Protocol for Cervical Cancer Screening:

Population

Recommendation

Aged less than 21 years

No screening

Aged 21-29 years

Cytology alone every 3 years

Aged 30-65 years

Any one of the following:

  • Cytology alone every 3 years
  • FDA-approved primary hrHPV testing alone every 5 years
  • Cotesting (hrHPV testing and cytology) every 5 years

Aged greater than 65 years

No screening after adequate negative prior screening results

Hysterectomy with removal of the cervix

No screening in individuals without a history of high-grade cervical precancerous lesions or cervical cancer


 

WHO Cervical Cancer Screening Guidelines:

Population

Strategy

Screening Test

Starting Age

Screening Interval

General population of women

Screen and Treat

or

Screen, Triage and Treat

HPV DNA as primary test

30 years

Every 5 to 10 years

Women living with HIV

Screen, Triage, and Treat only

HPV DNA as primary test

25 years

Every 3 to 5 years


 

Co-testing (Pap and Hr HPV) every 5 years starting at 25 years (Option A) is recommended for women aged 25 and older, typically in higher-resource settings where both Pap smear and HPV testing are accessible.
 

Hr HPV testing every 5 years starting at 30 years (Option C) is recommended for women aged 30 and older, as younger women tend to clear HPV infections on their own and are less likely to develop cervical cancer from HPV.
 

Pap smear every 5 years starting at 21 years (Option D) is not standard; Pap smears are typically done every 3 years starting at age 21 according to most guidelines.

questions.text: 26-year-old P1L1 presents with abdominal pain. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease for which she has undergone mitral valve replacement surgery and is on the oral tablet Warfarin 3mg OD. On examination, 14 weeks of abdominal mass were felt. On USG, an 8 X 6 cm unilocular cyst with a reticular pattern was observed in the left ovary. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Repeat USG after 6-12 weeks

Explanation:

The patient presents with abdominal pain, a history of mitral valve replacement, and an ovarian cyst with a reticular pattern on ultrasound, suggesting a benign ovarian cyst. The next line of management is to repeat USG after 6-12 weeks to monitor for any changes, as many unilocular cysts resolve spontaneously.
 

Functional Ovarian Cysts:

  • Arise from ovarian follicles during follicle maturation and ovulation.
  • Types:
    • Single Cysts: Most common, often a single follicular or corpus luteum cyst.
    • Multiple Cysts: Can occur in conditions like:
      • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
      • Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS)
      • FSH-secreting pituitary adenomas
  • Features:
    • Functional cysts are typically 3–7 cm, and those larger than 10 cm or persistent for more than 3 months may require further investigation for malignancy.
    • Related to hormonal variations.
    • Filled with clear fluid (unless hemorrhage occurs).
    • Benign, often asymptomatic
    • Typically resolve on their own
  • Management:
    • Observation: Most cysts resolve spontaneously within 4-6 months.
      • Follow-up: Regular ultrasound after 6-12 weeks to monitor persistent or enlarging cysts.
      • Symptomatic Treatment: Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) may be prescribed for pain or irregular menses.
      • Surgery: Indicated for cysts larger than 10 cm, persistent, or symptomatic (e.g., pain, torsion).
         

Measure CA 125 levels (Option A): Elevated CA 125 can indicate ovarian cancer but is often raised in benign conditions like menstruation, endometriosis, or pelvic inflammatory disease. It is primarily useful in postmenopausal women with suspected malignancy.

Surgical intervention (Option C): Immediate surgery is unnecessary for a simple ovarian cyst. Surgery is typically considered if the cyst persists, grows, or causes acute symptoms like torsion or rupture.


MRI pelvis (Option D): Transvaginal ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality for ovarian cysts. MRI is typically used for complex or uncertain cases, which is not necessary here.

questions.text: A couple presents with infertility even after 2 years of unprotected intercourse. The seminal analysis reveals a volume of 2 ml, concentration of 40 million/ml, progressive motility of 55%, and morphology of 45 %. The wife's hormone levels were normal, with bilateral spillage of dye from both fallopian tubes on HSG. What percentage of couples can be attributed to unexplained infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 25%

Explanation:

The couple has normal semen analysis, ovulation, and tubal patency, suggesting unexplained infertility in approximately 25% of such cases.

 

Unexplained infertility refers to infertile couples with normal ovulation, tubal patency, and semen analysis. Its prevalence ranges from 22-28%.


Semen Analysis and Normal Values:

  • First investigation for infertility in males.
  • Performed after 1 year of unprotected intercourse without conception or earlier if there are known risk factors for infertility.
  • Abstain: 2-7 days.
  • Analysis: Within 1 hour on the liquefied semen (takes 20-30 min).

 

Parameters

Normal (Normozoospermia)

(WHO 2021 Guidelines)

Volume

> 1.4 ml

pH

7.2-8.0

Concentration

At least 16 million/ ml

Total count

39 million/ejaculate

Total Motility

42% or more

Progressive motility

30% or more

Morphology (most important)

4% or more

Pus cells (WBC)

1-2 million/ml

Viability

54% or more

 

Note:

  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OATZ) means all parameters are subnormal, as seen in varicocele and smoking.
  • The most important parameters in sperm analysis are Morphology > Motility > Concentration.

questions.text: A 35-year-old P2L2 woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge and a normal cervix. The whiff test is positive. What is this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bacterial vaginosis

Explanation:

The positive whiff test with malodorous discharge in the female is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial Vaginosis (BV):

  • A polymicrobial condition characterized by an alteration in normal vaginal flora.
  • Minimal inflammatory response; few leukocytes in vaginal fluid.
  • Pathogenesis:
  • Decreased lactobacilli, leading to increased pH and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria.
  • Common bacteria: Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus spp., Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis.
  • Not sexually transmitted.
  • Symptoms:
  • 50% are asymptomatic.
  • Vaginal discharge: white, milky, non-viscous, and adherent.
  • Minimal vulval irritation.
  • Amsel's Criteria (Diagnostic Features):
  • White, milky, nonviscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall.
  • Discharge with pH >4.5.
  • Fishy odor on adding 10% KOH (whiff test).
  • Presence of clue cells on wet mount.

  • Reduced lactobacilli and increased pathogenic bacteria.
  • Complications:
    • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
    • Chorioamnionitis
    • Premature rupture of membranes (PROM)
    • Preterm labor
  • Treatment:
  • Metronidazole (DOC):
    • 400 mg twice daily for 7 days (effective in 85%).
    • A single 1 g dose cures only 45%.
  • Clindamycin:
    • 2% cream locally (85% effective).
    • Oral 300 mg daily for 7 days.
  • Alternatives:
    • Ampicillin, cephalosporin, tetracycline, doxycycline, or sulfa drugs.

 

Candida (Option A) causes thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge, itching, and presents with pseudohyphae and yeast cells on KOH mount, but not a fishy odor or positive whiff test.

 

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option C) causes frothy, greenish-yellow discharge with itching, burning, and motile trichomonas on wet mount, but lacks a fishy odor and positive whiff test.

 

Physiological cause (Option D) results in clear, odorless discharge that varies with the menstrual cycle and does not have a fishy odor or a positive whiff test.

questions.text: An athlete with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 presents with secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. Her laboratory investigations reveal FSH 2, LH 0.3, and TSH 1.2. Prolactin 20ng/ml. What is the underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Explanation:

The low FSH and LH levels with a history of low BMI in an athlete indicate reduced GnRH production, consistent with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
 

Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism (HH):

  • It results from hypothalamic or pituitary dysfunction, leading to inadequate gonadotropin secretion.
  • Classification:
    • Congenital HH:
      • Anosmic HH (e.g., Kallmann syndrome): Associated with impaired or absent sense of smell; MRI may show absent or abnormal olfactory bulbs.
      • Congenital Normosmic Isolated HH: Normal sense of smell.
    • Acquired HH: May result from tumors, trauma, weight loss, excessive exercise, stress, systemic illness, or medications.
  • Clinical Characteristics:
    • Androgen deficiency: Decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, muscle weakness, and increased adiposity.
    • Impaired or delayed pubertal sexual maturation.
    • Depressed mood, decreased vitality, reduced bone density, and infertility.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Low testosterone and low levels of pituitary hormones (LH and FSH).
    • Low serum levels of estradiol.
    • Stimulated intravenous GnRH test may help confirm the diagnosis.
    • MRI for anosmic HH may reveal anomalies in olfactory structures.
  • Management:
    • Hormonal Therapy: Used to stimulate sexual development and regularize menstrual cycles in cases of congenital HH.
    • Cause-Specific Therapy: Targeted treatment for acquired causes based on the underlying condition.
    • Fertility Treatment: Ovulation induction using GnRH or gonadotropins.

 

Primary ovarian failure (Option A) is marked by irregular or absent menstrual cycles, with elevated FSH and decreased estradiol levels indicating a primary ovarian defect. This condition typically results in sterility, which does not align with the patient’s suppressed FSH and LH levels in this case.

 

Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism (Option C) is associated with ovarian failure leading to high FSH and LH due to a lack of negative feedback from the ovaries. It is not relevant here as the patient’s gonadotropin levels are suppressed, not elevated.

 

Normogonadotropic Normogonadism (Option D) implies normal hypothalamic-pituitary function, with FSH and LH levels in the normal range. Amenorrhea in such cases is often due to PCOS or other structural or systemic causes, none of which align with the suppressed gonadotropins seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth. What is the first line management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of PCOS, which is characterized by menstrual irregularities, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. The first-line management of PCOS is lifestyle modifications, including weight loss, diet, and exercise. Even a 5% reduction in body weight can significantly improve hormonal balance, insulin sensitivity, ovulation, and metabolic outcomes.

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) Management:

Goals of Treatment: Managing menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, infertility, and preventing long-term risks like metabolic syndrome.

1. Lifestyle Modifications (First-line treatment for all PCOS patients)

  • Weight loss (>5% of body weight) improves hormonal balance, increases SHBG, and reduces insulin & testosterone levels.
  • Smoking cessation lowers DHEA & androgen levels while increasing estrogen levels.

2. Menstrual Cycle Regulation & Androgen Suppression

Treatment

Mechanism

Benefits

OCPs (First-line for menstrual regulation & hirsutism) (Option C)

Estrogen increases SHBG, reducing free testosterone; Progestogen suppresses LH & androgen production

Regulates cycles, reduces acne & hirsutism

Anti-androgenic OCPs (Preferred)

Cyproterone acetate or Drospirenone

Best for hirsutism & acne

Spironolactone + OCPs

Blocks androgen receptors

Reduces hirsutism & acne

Eflornithine Cream (Topical)

Inhibits hair growth

Used for facial hirsutism

3. Acne Management

  • Topical clindamycin (1%) or erythromycin (2%) for mild cases.
  • Isotretinoin for severe acne (teratogenic, avoid in pregnancy).

4. Ovulation Induction & Fertility Treatment

Drug

Mechanism

Benefits

Side Effects

Letrozole (Preferred Over Clomiphene Citrate)

Aromatase inhibitor

No anti-estrogenic effects on endometrium & cervix → higher pregnancy rates, monofollicular stimulation, no ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS)

Drowsiness

Clomiphene Citrate (Option D)

Selective estrogen receptor modulator

Induces ovulation in 80%, conception in 40-45%

Anti-estrogenic effects on endometrium & cervix lower fertility, OHSS in <1%

Tamoxifen (Resistant Cases)

Estrogen receptor modulator

Used when Clomiphene fails (80-160 mg for 5 days)

–

Dexamethasone (Adjunct)

Lowers adrenal androgens

Improves ovulation outcomes

–

5. Insulin Sensitizers (For insulin resistance & metabolic issues)

Drug

Mechanism

Benefits and side effects

Metformin (Option A)

Improves insulin sensitivity, reduces hepatic glucose production, lowers testosterone levels

Benefits: Increases ovulation (70-80%), conception (30-40%).
 

S/E: GI disturbances, lactic acidosis, avoid in liver/kidney disease

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) + Micronutrients

Lowers homocysteine, improves insulin resistance

Alternative to Metformin in some cases

Acarbose (Alternative to Metformin)

Delays glucose absorption

Used if Metformin is contraindicated

 

6. Surgery is reserved for cases where:

  • Medical therapy fails
  • Ovarian hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertility persists despite treatment
  • Recurrent pregnancy losses
     

Procedure: Laparoscopic ovarian drilling (LOD) using laser or unipolar electrocautery, targeting no more than four cysts per ovary. This helps restore the endocrine balance and improves fertility for 6-12 months. However, pelvic adhesions from surgery may reduce fertility, which can be minimized using hydroflotation techniques.

questions.text: OCPs are not protective for?
questions.solution:
OCPs are not protective for breast cancer.

 

Cancer Type

Effect of COC Use

Key Findings

Endometrial Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by ≥30%, with greater protection in long-term users. The effect persists for years after discontinuation.
  • More pronounced reduction seen in smokers, obese women, and those with low physical activity.

Ovarian Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by 30–50%, with greater protection in long-term users. The effect persists for 10–15 years after stopping, even with short-term use (≥6 months).
  • Protection extends to BRCA1/BRCA2 mutation carriers.

Colorectal Cancer

Protective
  • Risk reduced by 15–20%.

Breast Cancer

Increased Risk
  • COC use increases risk by 25%, especially in nulliparous women who start before age 24 and use it for >4 years.
  • If breast cancer develops, it is usually well-differentiated with a good prognosis.
  • The increased risk disappears after 10 years of stopping.

Cervical Cancer

Increased Risk
  • Prolonged COC use increases risk, particularly of adenocarcinoma of the cervix.
  • Women using COCs for ≥5 years have a higher risk, with risk increasing with longer duration.

questions.text: A 38 Y/o woman presents with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic discomfort, and frequent urination. On physical examination, her uterus is found to be irregularly enlarged. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Leiomyoma

Explanation:

This patient's symptoms of heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic discomfort, frequent urination, and an irregularly enlarged uterus are most consistent with a diagnosis of leiomyoma, also known as fibroids.

 

Leiomyoma:

Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle neoplasms that originate in myometrium.

 

Clinical features:

  • Asymptomatic (75%) - mostly an incidental finding
  • Abnormal uterine bleeding(AUB)(30%): Menorrhagia,metrorrhagia
  • Dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia
  • Subfertility
  • Pressure symptoms
    • Bladder symptoms: increased frequency or retention of urine
    • Rectal symptoms: constipation
  • Lower abdominal or pelvic pain or heaviness
  • Irregularly enlarged lower abdomen.

 

Endometriosis (Option A) also presents with pelvic pain and abnormal menstrual bleeding but an irregularly enlarged uterus is not seen.

 

An ovarian cyst (Option B) most commonly, is asymptomatic but increases the risk of ovarian torsion and presents with an adnexal mass but not an enlarged uterus.

 

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (Option D) is usually seen in obese women and presents with irregular menstrual bleeding along with hormonal symptoms such as hirsutism and acne.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with irregular menstrual cycles, acne, and excessive hair growth. An ultrasound reveals multiple ovarian cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

 

Explanation:

 

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances.

 

Components of PCOS:

  • Increased androgens
  • Ovulatory dysfunction
  • Polycystic ovaries

 

Clinical features:

  • Usually present in young women
  • Central obesity (BMI > 30kg/cm2), waistline> 88cm.
  • Oligomenorrhea, amenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance

 

Endometriosis (Option B) involves the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus and presents with pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea and infertility.

  • While it can cause irregular menstrual cycles, it does not typically cause acne, hirsutism, or multiple ovarian cysts.

 

Hypothyroidism (Option C) can cause menstrual irregularities, weight gain, and fatigue.

  • However, it does not commonly present with acne, hirsutism, or multiple ovarian cysts.

 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) (Option D): 

  • This condition can occur as a complication of Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART), particularly in individuals who have undergone ovulation induction with medication.
  • The ultrasound may reveal multiple ovarian cysts, but the clinical presentation is typically characterized by acute abdominal pain rather than irregular menstrual cycles, acne, or hirsutism.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of a yellowish-green, foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She reports painful urination and pain during intercourse & no itching. On speculum examination, her vulva and vaginal walls appear inflamed. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trichomonas vaginalis

Explanation:
Trichomonas vaginitis is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age.

Symptoms include :

  • Sudden, profuse, yellowish-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge
  • Irritation and itching in and around the vaginal opening
  • Painful urination
  • Pain during intercourse
  • Recurrent infections
  • Inflamed vulva
  • Inflamed vaginal walls with small, punctate hemorrhages ("strawberry cervix")

 

Candida albicans (Option B):

  • Characterized by a scanty, white, curdy vaginal discharge
  • Intense vulvovaginal itching present leading to erosions causing splash dysuria and dyspareunia

 

Gardnerella vaginalis (Option C):

  • Characterized by a foul-smelling, thin, gray-white, or green-yellow vaginal discharge
  • Absence of itching, dysuria, or dyspareunia

 

Neisseria gonorhhea (Option D):

  • It does not typically cause vaginitis alone.
  • It can cause cervicitis, whose symptoms can overlap with that of vaginitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for evaluation of her fertility status. She has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. Which of the following is the single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH)

 

Explanation:

  • Anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) levels correlate with the number of antral follicles in the ovaries and provide a direct measure of ovarian reserve.
  • AMH is less variable throughout the menstrual cycle and is considered the most reliable single test for assessing ovarian reserve.

Tests for Ovarian Reserve:

Test Name

Description

Key Points

Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH)

A hormone produced by ovarian antral follicles.
  • Blood test reflecting the remaining quantity of eggs.
  • Not affected by the menstrual cycle.
  • The single best test for assessing her ovarian reserve

Antral Follicle Count (AFC)

Ultrasound count of the small follicles (antral follicles) within the ovaries.
  • Direct visual assessment.
  • Can vary with the cycle.
  • Baseline assessment and monitoring.

Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)

Measures the level of FSH, which stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.
  • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle.
  • Initial screening of ovarian function.

Estradiol (E2)

Measures the level of estradiol, an estrogen produced by growing follicles.
  • Blood test done on day 3 of the menstrual cycle.
  • High levels can mask high FSH levels, so they are used in conjunction with FSH.

Inhibin B

Measures the level of inhibin B, which reflects the number of antral follicles.
  • Blood test on day 5 of the menstrual cycle.

Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test (CCCT)

Measures FSH and estradiol before and after taking clomiphene citrate.
  • Two blood tests: day 3 and day 10.
  • Higher FSH levels on day 10 indicate lower reserve.
  • Used for detailed functional assessment.

 

Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) on day 3 (Option A):

  • Elevated levels of FSH on the third day of the menstrual cycle can indicate diminished ovarian reserve.
  • However, FSH levels can fluctuate and be influenced by various factors, making it a less reliable single test.

 

Estradiol on day 3 (Option B):

  • Elevated estradiol levels on the third day of the menstrual cycle can suggest a diminished ovarian reserve.
  • However, like FSH, estradiol levels can be variable and influenced by other factors.

 

Serum inhibin levels on day 5 (Option D):

  • Inhibin B levels can reflect the size and function of the ovarian follicle pool, but they can be more variable and less consistent than AMH.

questions.text: A teenage girl presents with a history of primary amenorrhea. On physical examination, an imperforate hymen is observed. What karyotype analysis would you consider for further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 46XX:

  • This is the normal female karyotype. An imperforate hymen is a congenital anomaly that can occur in 46XX females. It causes primary amenorrhea due to the obstruction of menstrual flow (cryptomenorrhea) and typically presents with cyclic abdominal pain and a bulging hymen. This is the correct karyotype to consider for further evaluation in this case.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 46XY:

  • This karyotype indicates a genetically male individual. Disorders of sexual development (DSD), such as Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS), may present with a female phenotype and amenorrhea but would not typically involve an imperforate hymen. Therefore, this is unlikely in the context of an imperforate hymen.

Option C - 45XO:

  • This karyotype is characteristic of Turner syndrome, a condition associated with primary amenorrhea and other clinical features such as short stature and ovarian dysgenesis. However, Turner syndrome would not be associated with an imperforate hymen, making this option less likely.

Option D - 47XXY:

This karyotype corresponds to Klinefelter syndrome, which is a condition affecting males. It typically presents with small testes, gynecomastia, and infertility, but not with primary amenorrhea or an imperforate hymen. Thus, this option is irrelevant in this context.

questions.text: At ovulation, what is released?

choices.text: Secondary oocyte at the end of meiosis I
Secondary oocyte at the end of meiosis II
Primary oocyte at the end of meiosis I
Primary oocyte at the end of meiosis II

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Secondary oocyte at the end of meiosis I :

  • At ovulation, a secondary oocyte is released. This oocyte has completed meiosis I but has not yet completed meiosis II. The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II and will only complete meiosis II if fertilization occurs.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Secondary oocyte at the end of meiosis II:

  • This option is incorrect because the secondary oocyte only completes meiosis II if it is fertilized by a sperm. Therefore, at ovulation, the oocyte is still in metaphase II, not at the end of meiosis II.

Option C - Primary oocyte at the end of meiosis I:

  • This option is incorrect because the primary oocyte completes meiosis I to form the secondary oocyte before ovulation. It is the secondary oocyte, not the primary oocyte, that is released during ovulation.

Option D - Primary oocyte at the end of meiosis II:

  • This option is incorrect because primary oocytes are arrested in prophase I until puberty. The primary oocyte undergoes meiosis I to become a secondary oocyte, which is what is released during ovulation. Meiosis II is not completed unless fertilization occurs.

questions.text: What is the typical time between fertilization and implantation in human reproduction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 8 days:

  • Implantation usually occurs around 6 to 10 days after fertilization, with the average being about 8 days. By this time, the embryo has developed into a blastocyst and is ready to implant into the uterine lining.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 2 days:

  • This is too short for implantation. After fertilization, the zygote undergoes multiple cell divisions and travels through the fallopian tube towards the uterus. At this point, the embryo is still in transit.

Option C - 14 days:

  • By 14 days after fertilization, the embryo should already be implanted, and early pregnancy may be detectable through specific hormonal changes.

Option D -16 days:

  • If implantation has not occurred by this time, the embryo would likely not be viable, as the uterine environment may no longer support implantation.

questions.text: A patient presents with a new 2 cm black nodular mass near an episiotomy scar that is painful and expands during menstruation. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Options A - Endometriosis:

  • Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. When it occurs near an episiotomy scar, it can form a nodular mass that is painful and enlarges during menstruation due to hormonal influences, which matches the scenario described.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Melanoma:

  • A melanoma is a malignant tumor of melanocytes, often appearing as a pigmented lesion. Although it can present as a black nodular mass, it would not typically be associated with pain that fluctuates with the menstrual cycle.

Option C - Foreign body granuloma:

  • This is an inflammatory reaction to retained foreign material, typically presenting as a firm, non-pigmented, non-cyclic mass. It is unlikely to enlarge or cause pain during menstruation.

Option D - Inclusion cyst:

An inclusion cyst forms when epithelial cells are trapped beneath the surface of the skin, often after trauma or surgery (like an episiotomy). These cysts are typically smooth, non-pigmented, and painless, and do not fluctuate with the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: Tubectomy is typically performed at which part of the fallopian tube, and why?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Isthmus - Narrowest part :

  • The isthmus is the narrowest section of the fallopian tube, which makes it the ideal location for tubectomy.
  • This narrow part ensures that when the tube is cut or blocked, the likelihood of the eggs passing through or reconnections forming is minimal, thus providing effective sterilization.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ampulla - Uniform thickness of muscle:

  • The ampulla is indeed a part of the fallopian tube, and while it has a relatively uniform thickness of muscle, this is not the primary reason for choosing this site for tubectomy.

Option B - Ampulla - Widest part:

  • The ampulla is the widest portion of the fallopian tube, which facilitates the passage of the ovum. However, this wide lumen is not a typical location for tubectomy as it may not provide optimal control for preventing fertilization.

Option C - Ampulla-Isthmus Junction - Site of fertilization:

  • This is the region where fertilization most commonly occurs, but performing a tubectomy here could risk the chance of incomplete sterilization.

questions.text: Which of the following is the tumor marker for ovarian solid cystic mass in a 20 year old female?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ca125, AFP, HCG, LDH:

  • In a 20-year-old female with an ovarian solid cystic mass, germ cell tumors are more common.
  • AFP and HCG are key markers for germ cell tumors like yolk sac tumors and choriocarcinoma, respectively.
  • LDH is specifically elevated in dysgerminomas, another germ cell tumor.
  • Ca125 is included to assess for the possibility of epithelial ovarian cancer, though it is less common in this age group.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are incorrect as these are fond in a perimenopausal women and are markers for mucinous and epithelial tumours

questions.text: Identify the type of uterus shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Didelphys Uterus:

  • The Didelphys Uterus is the correct answer.
  • This condition involves two completely separate uterine cavities, often with dual cervices and sometimes even two vaginas.
  • The image likely showed these distinct, separate uterine structures, indicating a didelphys uterus, distinguishing it from other types of uterine anomalies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bicornuate Uterus:

  • This type of uterus has a deep indentation at the fundus, resulting in a heart-shaped external contour. The cavity is divided into two distinct horns, often giving it a “Y” or “V” shape. It is a congenital anomaly that occurs due to incomplete fusion of the Mullerian ducts.

Option C - Arcuate Uterus:

  • An arcuate uterus is a mild uterine anomaly where the top of the uterus is slightly indented or concave but does not form a significant separation. It is the least severe Mullerian duct anomaly and usually has minimal impact on fertility.

Option D - Aseptate Uterus:

  • An aseptate uterus (or septate uterus) has a fibrous or muscular septum dividing the uterine cavity partially or completely. The external shape of the uterus is typically normal, but the internal cavity is separated by the septum, which can affect pregnancy outcomes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea. An ultrasound (USG) shows a cystic ovarian mass with a "ground glass" appearance. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Endometriosis:

  • Endometriosis can cause the formation of ovarian cysts known as endometriomas, also called "chocolate cysts." These cysts contain thick, old blood and are characterized by a "ground glass" appearance on ultrasound. This is the correct answer as it best matches the clinical scenario.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intramural fibroid:

  • These are non-cancerous growths within the muscular wall of the uterus. They typically appear as solid masses on ultrasound rather than a cystic mass with a "ground glass" appearance.

Option B - Adenomyoma:

  • This condition involves the presence of endometrial tissue within the uterine muscle, leading to a diffuse or localized thickening of the uterine wall. Ultrasound usually shows a heterogeneous mass in the myometrium, but not a cystic structure with a "ground glass" appearance.

Option D - Myomatous polyp:

  • These are benign growths that arise from the uterine lining or muscle, often presenting as solid, pedunculated masses within the uterine cavity. They do not typically present with a "ground glass" appearance on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, gravida 2, para 2, with a history of cervical lengthening, is considering surgical options. Given her history, what is the choice of surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Fothergill Procedure

Explanation:

  • The Fothergill procedure is a surgical technique used for cervical incompetence. It involves shortening the cervix to strengthen it, typically used in cases of cervical incompetence where there is a need to support the cervix during pregnancy to prevent preterm delivery.
  • Indication: Used for cervical incompetence in cases where previous cervical lengthening or other methods have failed.

Incorrect Options:

(Option B) McCall Culdoplasty:

  • Explanation: McCall culdoplasty is a surgical procedure performed to support the vaginal apex (top of the vagina) and prevent prolapse. It is commonly used in the context of post-hysterectomy pelvic support.
  • Indication: Primarily used for pelvic organ prolapse or after a hysterectomy, not specifically for cervical incompetence.

(Option C) LeFort Procedure:

  • Explanation: The LeFort procedure is a type of pelvic reconstructive surgery, but it is more commonly associated with treating conditions related to pelvic support after a hysterectomy or in cases of prolapse.
  • Indication: Usually not used for cervical incompetence; more applicable to pelvic reconstructive issues.

(Option D) Hysterectomy:

  • Explanation: Hysterectomy is the surgical removal of the uterus. It is not typically used to address cervical incompetence directly but is performed for conditions like fibroids, cancer, or severe endometriosis.
  • Indication: This is not the first choice for cervical incompetence; it would only be considered if there were other significant indications for removing the uterus.

questions.text: In sacrocolpopexy (Sacrocolposuspension), the surgical mesh is attached to which bony landmark?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sacral promontory:

  • In sacrocolpopexy, a surgical procedure used to treat pelvic organ prolapse, the mesh is attached to the anterior longitudinal ligament over the sacral promontory. This provides strong support to the vaginal vault or uterus, effectively restoring normal pelvic anatomy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ischial spine:

  • The ischial spine is a point of attachment for ligaments and muscles in the pelvis but is not used as an attachment site for the mesh in sacrocolpopexy.

Option C - Pubic symphysis:

  • The pubic symphysis is the joint between the two pubic bones at the front of the pelvis. It is not involved in sacrocolpopexy, as this procedure focuses on securing the vagina or uterus to the sacral promontory, located posteriorly in the pelvis.

Option D - Ischial tuberosity:

  • The ischial tuberosity is the lower part of the pelvis, serving as an attachment point for the hamstring muscles. It is not relevant to sacrocolpopexy, where the goal is to support pelvic organs by securing the mesh to the sacral promontory.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of cervical erosion and spotting for the past 2 months. What is the next best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - LBC + HPV (Liquid-Based Cytology + Human Papillomavirus Testing):

  • This combination is the most appropriate for evaluating the cervical erosion and spotting, given the strong link between HPV infection and cervical dysplasia/cancer. This approach ensures both cytological assessment and identification of any high-risk HPV infection, providing a comprehensive evaluation for this patient.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B - Pap smear + HSV (Papanicolaou Test + Herpes Simplex Virus Testing):

  • The Pap smear is a standard screening tool for cervical cancer, while HSV testing is useful for diagnosing herpes infections. However, HSV testing is not indicated in this scenario as her symptoms are not typical of an HSV infection.

Option C - Pap smear + HBV (Papanicolaou Test + Hepatitis B Virus Testing):

  • The Pap smear is relevant for cervical cancer screening, but HBV testing is unrelated to her current symptoms and history. HBV is associated with liver disease, not cervical pathology.

Option D - LBC + HSV (Liquid-Based Cytology + Herpes Simplex Virus Testing):

  • While LBC is appropriate for evaluating cervical cells, HSV testing is unnecessary in this case as there are no clinical signs pointing to a herpes infection.

questions.text: A G5P4 woman comes for her first routine sonography. She has four daughters and desires a boy this time, asking for sex determination. Based on ethical and legal guidelines, which action would you choose?

choices.text: Check routine ANC and sex for developmental abnormalities and do not reveal gender to the patient
Check routine ANC and sex for developmental abnormalities and do reveal the gender to the patient
Reveal the gender if it is a girl
Check only routine ANC; do not check the sex of the fetus

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Check only routine ANC; do not check the sex of the fetus:

  • This option strictly follows legal and ethical standards, focusing on the health of the mother and fetus without engaging in sex determination, preventing any gender-based bias.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Check routine ANC and sex for developmental abnormalities and do not reveal gender to the patient:

  • This approach aligns with routine prenatal care, ensuring fetal health and identifying abnormalities without disclosing gender. This option adheres to legal and ethical standards in countries where sex determination is restricted.

Option B - Check routine ANC and sex for developmental abnormalities and do reveal the gender to the patient:

  • Although this involves proper antenatal care, revealing the gender breaches legal and ethical guidelines, especially in areas where disclosing fetal sex is illegal to prevent gender-based discrimination.

Option C - Reveal the gender if it is a girl:

  • Selectively revealing gender based on the result is unethical and illegal. It promotes gender bias and violates laws against sex determination.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD as a known case of cervical cancer. On further evaluation, the pelvic sidewall was found to be involved, and hydronephrosis was also seen. Identify the stage of cancer.
questions.solution:
Option C - Stage 3B:

  • This stage is characterized by the involvement of the pelvic sidewall and/or hydronephrosis (or a non-functioning kidney) caused by the tumor. Both the pelvic sidewall involvement and hydronephrosis are key features.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stage 2B:

  • This stage involves the extension of the cancer beyond the cervix to the parametrium, but not to the pelvic sidewall or lower third of the vagina. Hydronephrosis is not present.

Option B - Stage 2A:

  • In this stage, the cancer extends beyond the cervix but does not involve the parametrium or pelvic sidewall. The vagina may be involved, but not the lower third. There is no involvement of the pelvic sidewall or hydronephrosis.

Option D - Stage 3A:

  • Cancer at this stage involves the lower third of the vagina but does not extend to the pelvic sidewall. Hydronephrosis is not present.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a mass felt on the perineum. On examination, a palpable uterus is noted, and from the os, one finger can pass. She delivered 20 years ago.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Myxomatous Polyp:

  • A myxomatous polyp is a benign, soft, gelatinous growth that can arise from the endometrial or cervical tissue. Given the history of remote childbirth, the polyp could have developed over time. The description of a mass on the perineum with a palpable uterus and a cervix that allows one finger to pass is consistent with a prolapsing myxomatous polyp.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Uterine Inversion:

  • Uterine inversion typically occurs immediately after childbirth and involves the uterus turning inside out. It presents acutely with severe pain and shock, not 20 years post-delivery. A palpable uterus with this scenario is unlikely, making uterine inversion an improbable diagnosis.

Option C - Placental Polyp:

  • Placental polyps result from retained placental tissue following childbirth or abortion. Given that the patient delivered 20 years ago, a placental polyp is unlikely because it would have presented earlier with complications like bleeding or infection.

Option – D Hypertrophied Cervix:

  • Cervical hypertrophy refers to an enlargement of the cervix, which can cause a mass effect. However, the clinical description of a perineal mass with a palpable uterus suggests something protruding rather than just a thickened cervix.

questions.text: Identify the degree of uterine prolapse.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Degree 3:

  • This degree of prolapse involves the organ protruding through the vaginal opening but remaining within the confines of the external genitalia. It is visibly external but not entirely outside the pelvis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Degree 1:

  • This level of prolapse refers to a situation where the organ (e.g., the uterus or bladder) descends into the vaginal canal but does not extend past the vaginal opening. It is still within the pelvic cavity.

Option B - Degree 2:

  • In this stage, the organ extends to the vaginal opening but does not protrude outside the vaginal orifice. It is partially outside the pelvic cavity but not yet entirely external.

Option D - Degree 4:

  • This is the most severe form of prolapse. The organ is entirely outside the pelvis, and it can be observed protruding beyond the vaginal orifice.

questions.text: What is this grid system used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Prolapse:

  • The POP-Q (Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification) system is specifically designed to assess and classify pelvic organ prolapse. It provides a standardized method to evaluate the extent and severity of prolapse, allowing for more accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

Incorrect options B, C and D:

  • The POP-Q system is not used for diagnosing or managing vulvar cancer. Endometrial cancer or Abruption placenta.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses is an adnexal mass on ultrasound showing incomplete septation and a cogwheel appearance most consistent with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Hydrosalpinx:

  • This condition involves the accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tube, which can cause it to appear as a cystic mass on ultrasound. While hydrosalpinx typically appears as a smooth-walled, anechoic structure, it can sometimes show incomplete septation or a cogwheel appearance, especially in chronic cases with associated inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Follicular ovarian cyst:

  • These are simple cysts formed from unruptured ovarian follicles. On ultrasound, they typically appear as round, anechoic structures with a thin, smooth wall and do not usually display incomplete septation or a cogwheel appearance.

Option C - Endometriosis:

  • Endometriosis can cause cysts called endometriomas, which often have a "chocolate" appearance due to old blood. On ultrasound, endometriomas typically present as well-defined cystic lesions with a homogeneous internal echogenicity and do not usually show incomplete septation or a cogwheel appearance.

Option D - Hemorrhagic ovarian cyst:

  • This type of cyst occurs when a follicular cyst bleeds into itself. It can present with internal echoes or a complex appearance on ultrasound, including a cogwheel appearance due to blood clot formation and septations. However, incomplete septation is less characteristic compared to a hydrosalpinx.

questions.text: A 55-year-old pre-menopausal woman is diagnosed with early invasive breast cancer. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) shows that the tumor is estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) and progesterone receptor positive (PR+). Lymph node biopsy reveals metastatic involvement. The oncology team is discussing adjuvant therapy options. The drug used in a 55-year-old pre-menopausal patient with ER+, PR+ on IHC along with lymph node positive and diagnosed with early invasive breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tamoxifen

Explanation:

Tamoxifen is the correct choice because:

  • Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that blocks estrogen receptors on tumor cells, thereby inhibiting estrogen-driven tumor growth.
  • Tamoxifen is used in patients of all age groups, ER +ve patients and used in both pre-menopausal and post-menopausal women
  • It is used as adjuvant chemotherapy and reduces the recurrence rate 25%

 

Anastrozole (Option B): Anastrozole (aromatase inhibitor) is better tolerated than Tamoxifen but is not indicated in pre-menopausal women.

Trastuzumab (Option C): Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that blocks HER-2/Neu receptors. It is not indicated for hormone receptor-positive breast cancer without HER2 positivity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient was diagnosed with cervical carcinoma and radiotherapy has been planned. The radiation oncologist is reviewing the treatment plan focusing on Point A, which is a key reference point for radiation delivery. What is the dose of radiation in point A radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B. 7000 centigray

Explanation:

Point A receives 7000 centigray because:

  • Point A is 2cm above and 2cm lateral to external OS
    • Here ureter is under the uterine artery
    • Up to 7000 to 8000 RADs given here
  • Point B is 3cm lateral to point A
    • This point corresponds to obturator lymph nodes at the pelvic side walls
    • Up to 6000 RADS given here

The other doses of 2500 (Option A), 5000 (Option C) and 10,000 (Option D) centigray are incorrect for Point A radiation therapy in cervical cancer. The standard dose at Point A is 7000 centigray, which provides optimal tumor control while staying within tolerance limits of surrounding tissues.

questions.text: Cervarix vaccine is effective against which of the following Human papillomavirus serotypes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HPV 16 and 18

Explanation:

  • Cervarix is a bivalent HPV vaccine specifically targeting high-risk oncogenic serotypes 16 and 18.

 

HPV 6 and 11 (Option B): These are low-risk types primarily causing genital warts, targeted by Gardasil but not Cervarix.

HPV 6 and 16 (Option C): This combination includes one low-risk (6) and one high-risk (16) type. Cervarix only targets high-risk types 16 and 18.

HPV 11 and 18 (Option D): This combination includes one low-risk (11) and one high-risk (18) type. Cervarix specifically targets only high-risk types 16 and 18.

questions.text: What content is present in the contraceptive shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nonoxynol-9

Explanation:

The image shows a vaginal contraceptive sponge that contains Nonoxynol-9 as its active ingredient.

  • Device type: Vaginal sponge
  • Active ingredient: Nonoxynol-9 (spermicide)
  • Duration: Effective for 24 hours
  • Design: Includes an attached band for easy removal

Usage Characteristics:

  • Inserted vaginally before intercourse
  • Provides barrier and spermicidal protection
  • Must remain in place for at least 6 hours after intercourse
  • Should not be left in place for more than 24 hours

 

Menfegol (Option B): This compound has in vitro activity against HIV and is used in male condoms, not in vaginal sponges.

Octoxynol-8 (Option C): This has anti-spermicidal activity and is used in condoms, not in vaginal sponges.

questions.text: Identify the condition that is least likely to cause postmenopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ovarian follicular cyst

Explanation:

  • Ovarian follicular cysts are the least likely cause of postmenopausal bleeding among the given options.

 

Endometrial CA (Option A): This is one of the most common causes of postmenopausal bleeding, accounting for approximately 10% of cases. Any postmenopausal bleeding must be evaluated to rule out endometrial cancer as it is often the first sign of the disease.

Granulosa cell tumor (Option B): This is an estrogen-producing ovarian tumor that can cause endometrial hyperplasia and subsequent bleeding. The excess estrogen production stimulates the endometrium, potentially leading to irregular bleeding even in postmenopausal women.

Genital tract trauma (Option C): While not as common as endometrial cancer, trauma to the genital tract can cause bleeding at any age. This may occur due to injury during intercourse, medical procedures, or other traumatic events to the genital area.

questions.text: The investigation of choice for ovarian torsion is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) USG Doppler

Explanation:

  • USG Doppler is the investigation of choice for diagnosing ovarian torsion due to its ability to assess ovarian blood flow and morphology. It is non-invasive, readily available, and provides real-time assessment without radiation exposure.

USG findings in ovarian torsion:

  • Ovarian appearance: Swollen and edematous
  • Shape: Globular configuration
  • Additional findings: Free fluid in the peritoneal cavity
  • Blood flow: Disruption in normal adnexal flow

 

Clinically correlated (Option B) is important but cannot be used as the sole diagnostic method, as symptoms vary and imaging is required for confirmation.

MRI (Option C) is not the first-line investigation as it is time-consuming, not suitable in emergencies, and less readily available.

CT abdomen (Option D) is not ideal for gynecologic emergencies due to radiation exposure, less specificity, and time-consuming nature.

questions.text: A young lady gave a history of unprotected intercourse four days back. She is requesting an emergency contraception. Which of the following is most suitable in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IUCD

Explanation:

  • Implantation of the embryo takes place earliest during 6th day after intercourse
  • IUCD is effective for up to 5 days following unprotected intercourse
  • IUCD induces a foreign body-like action causing aseptic inflammation of the endometrium, reducing the chances of implantation
  • Ulipristal acetate is another method that is effective up to 5 days following unprotected coitus

 

Lng (Levonorgestrel) (Option A): Contains progesterone and must be used within 72 hrs of unprotected intercourse. It is not suitable in this case as 4 days have already passed.

OCP (Option C): Combined oral contraceptive pills (Yuzpe regimen) can be used for emergency contraception but are less effective than Levonorgestrel or IUCD and must also be taken within 72 hours.

Misoprostol (Option D): Used in medical abortion, it is not indicated for emergency contraception.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female with amenorrhoea complained of urinary retention and cyclical abdominal pain. A suprapubic bulge is felt and a bluish hue is seen on the vaginal opening. What condition does this female have?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Imperforate hymen:

  • It is a congenital condition where the hymen fails to perforate during fetal development.
  • This condition leads to the accumulation of menstrual blood in the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), causing symptoms such as amenorrhea (absence of menstruation), urinary retention due to pressure on the bladder, and a visible bulge at the vaginal introitus.
  • The bluish hue seen on physical examination is due to the blood collected behind the imperforate hymen.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Transverse vaginal septum:

  • A transverse vaginal septum is a horizontal wall of tissue that divides the vagina into upper and lower segments.
  • This can cause obstruction of menstrual flow, leading to amenorrhea, but typically does not cause a suprapubic bulge or a visible bluish hue.

Option C - Longitudinal vaginal septum:

  • A longitudinal vaginal septum is a vertical partition within the vagina that results from incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts.
  • It usually does not lead to amenorrhea, urinary retention, or a visible bluish hue.

Option D - Lateral fusion defects:

  • Lateral fusion defects refer to abnormalities in the fusion of the Müllerian ducts, leading to conditions such as uterine didelphys or bicornuate uterus.
  • They do not typically result in amenorrhea, urinary retention, or the described bulges.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most potent natural estrogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Estradiol (E2):

  • It is the most potent natural estrogen in the body. It is the primary estrogen produced by the ovaries during the reproductive years and plays a crucial role in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and the development of secondary sexual characteristics.
  • It has the highest affinity for estrogen receptors compared to other natural estrogens, making it the most potent

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Estriol:

  • It is Less potent than estradiol and primarily produced during pregnancy.

Option C - Conjugated estrogen:

  • It is a mixture of estrogens, used in hormone replacement therapy but not naturally occurring.

Option D – Estrone:

  • Less potent than estradiol, and more abundant after menopause.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with intermenstrual bleeding following the insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD). She reports no other complications. What is the most appropriate initial management step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Reassure the patient and observe

Explanation:

Intermenstrual bleeding is a common side effect following IUD insertion. It occurs due to the body's adjustment to the device and can persist for a few cycles. Management includes:

  • Reassurance and observation as the first-line approach
  • Tranexamic acid or NSAIDs can be used during the first few cycles to manage bleeding if needed

Remove the IUD (Option A): Removal is generally not necessary unless there are additional signs of complications such as severe pain, abnormal discharge, or evidence of infection.

Perform a pelvic ultrasound (Option C): While ultrasound might be considered if there are additional symptoms or concerns, it is not routinely needed solely for intermenstrual bleeding following IUD insertion.

Prescribe hormonal therapy (Option D): Hormonal therapy is not the first-line treatment for intermenstrual bleeding after IUD insertion. The primary approach is to observe and manage symptoms conservatively unless there are indications for further intervention.

questions.text: Identify the device.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lippes Loop

Explanation:

The image shows a Lippes Loop, which is a 1st generation IUD. It has a characteristic S-shaped design made of plastic.

Lippe’s Loop

 

Features of Lippes Loop:
  • Non-medicated device
  • Has a high failure rate

Mechanism of Action:
  • Foreign body reaction
  • Cellular/Biochemical changes in endometrium/uterine fluids
  • Impair viability of gamete
  • Reduce chances of fertilization, rather than implantation

Mirena and Progestasert (Options A & D): These are 3rd Generation IUDs containing hormones, specifically progesterone. They have a different T-shaped design.

Copper T (Option C): A 2nd Generation IUD that contains copper and has a T-shaped design, unlike the S-shaped device shown.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with intermenstrual spotting during the first month after IUCD insertion. She has no other complications. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Observation and reassurance

Explanation:Intermenstrual spotting during the first month after IUCD insertion is a common occurrence. When there are no additional symptoms or complications, the most appropriate management is observation and reassurance.

Iron supplements and reassurance (Option A): Iron supplements are unnecessary unless anemia is evident. Spotting alone doesn't warrant supplementation

Remove the IUCD (Option B) is unnecessary unless the patient develops severe complications or requests its removal.

Oral antibiotics (Option D) are not indicated unless there are signs of infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne, excessive hair growth, and increased serum insulin and testosterone levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations of the patient indicate Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS).

  • PCOS is the most common endocrine disorder among women of reproductive age.
  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances.
  • Characteristic presentation includes:
    • Irregular menstrual cycles
    • Hirsutism (excessive hair growth)
    • Acne
    • Signs of insulin resistance
    • Elevated serum testosterone levels
  • PCOS is the leading cause of hirsutism in women.
  • Endometriosis (Option B): Endometriosis primarily presents with dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, and infertility. The absence of these symptoms and presence of hyperandrogenism rules out this diagnosis. Additionally, endometriosis does not cause elevated testosterone or insulin resistance.
  • Ovarian Tumor (Option C): While ovarian tumors can cause hormonal imbalances, they typically present with more acute onset of symptoms and often include pelvic pain or bloating. The chronic nature of symptoms and classic presentation of PCOS make this diagnosis less likely.
  • Hypothyroidism (Option D): Hypothyroidism presents with fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and often hair thinning rather than excessive hair growth. It does not cause elevated testosterone levels or the androgenic symptoms seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulligravida presents with no cystocele and no rectocele but has a third-degree uterine prolapse. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Abdominal sling surgery

Explanation:

  • Abdominal sling surgery, also known as sacrohysteropexy or uterine suspension, involves using a synthetic mesh or native tissue to support the uterus by attaching it to the sacrum.
  • This approach is beneficial for young women with uterine prolapse who wish to preserve their fertility and sexual function.
  • Abdominal sling surgery, also known as sacrohysteropexy or uterine suspension, involves using a synthetic mesh or native tissue to support the uterus by attaching it to the sacrum.
  • This approach is beneficial for young women with uterine prolapse who wish to preserve their fertility and sexual function.

Category of patient

Treatment of Uterine Prolapse

Nulliparous or congenital prolapse

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation

Pregnancy & postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks POG)
  • Pelvic floor exercises

<40 Years
  • Fothergill’s repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar’s procedure

>40 Years - with completed family

Vaginal hysterectomy & pelvic floor repair

>60 Years - unit for surgery
  • Le-fort’s repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn’t want to retain sexual function

Degrees of uterine prolapse:

First degree

The uterus descends downward, but the external os (opening of the cervix) remains inside the vagina.

Second degree

The uterine body remains inside the vagina while the external os protrudes outside the vaginal introitus.

Third degree (Procidentia)

The cervix, uterine body, and fundus descend to lie outside the introitus.

The complete uterus protrudes outside the vagina.

LeFort Colpocleisis (Option A ) is a surgical procedure often used for older women who no longer desire vaginal intercourse. This procedure involves closing the vaginal canal partially to provide support for the prolapsed uterus. It is not suitable for young, nulliparous women who might want to preserve their fertility and sexual function.

Fothergill operation (Option B) also known as the Manchester procedure, is a surgical technique that involves amputation of the cervix and suspension of the uterus. While it preserves the uterus, it may not be the best option for severe third-degree prolapse in a young woman, particularly if future pregnancy is a consideration.

Shirodkar procedure (Option C) is typically used for cervical incompetence and involves the placement of a cervical cerclage to prevent preterm birth. It is not an appropriate treatment for uterine prolapse.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best post-coital contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Levonorgestrel (LNG)

Explanation: Levonorgestrel (LNG) is the drug of choice for emergency contraception.

Key Features:

  • Contains progesterone
  • Known as the drug of choice (DOC) for emergency contraception
  • Trade name: iPill

Advantages:

  • Least side effects among available options
  • Single pill administration
  • No interference with menstrual cycle

Dosage:

  • 0.75 mg × 2 tablets taken immediately (stat)
  • Alternative: 0.75 mg 1 tablet stat and another after 12 hours
  • Single 1.5 mg tablet commonly used

Estrogen (Option B): Estrogen alone is not recommended for emergency contraception due to its significant side effect profile including nausea and thromboembolic event.

Norethisterone (Option C): This progestin is primarily indicated for menstrual disorders and is not approved for emergency contraception.

Ulipristal acetate (Option D): While effective for up to 120 hours post-intercourse, ulipristal acetate is not considered the first-line emergency contraceptive. It requires prescription, has more contraindications, and is more expensive than levonorgestrel.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents for her annual checkup with no specific complaints. As part of preventive screening, which cancer screening test should be prioritized based on the most common malignancy affecting females?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mammogram

Explanation:

Breast cancer is the most common malignancy in females worldwide, making mammogram screening essential for early detection.

  • Mammography is the gold standard screening tool for breast cancer
  • Recommended starting at age 40-50 years (varies by guidelines)
  • Can detect tumors before they become clinically palpable

Pap Smear (Option B) is used to screen for cervical cancer, which is less common than breast cancer.

Transvaginal ultrasound (Option C) is used to evaluate pelvic organs, such as the ovaries and uterus, and is typically performed for symptomatic patients (e.g., pelvic pain or abnormal bleeding). It is not a standard screening tool for any specific cancer.

Colonoscopy (Option D) is used to screen colorectal cancer, which affects both genders and has lower incidence in females compared to breast cancer.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P2 requests immediate postpartum contraception after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. She expresses interest in an intrauterine device (IUD). What is the recommended timeframe for safe postplacental IUD insertion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 48 hours

Explanation:Post-placental IUD insertion can be safely performed within 48 hours of delivery. This timing allows for immediate postpartum contraception while the cervix is still dilated and the uterus is easily accessible.

  • IUD can be inserted immediately following placental delivery
  • The 48-hour window provides optimal timing for insertion
  • Specialized sponge holder is used for high fundal placement
  • Success rates show 88% retention during uterine involution

24 hours (Option A): While insertion is possible within 24 hours, the safe window extends up to 48 hours, making this timeframe unnecessarily restrictive.

6 weeks (Option C): Delaying contraception for six weeks increases the risk of unintended pregnancy in the immediate postpartum period.

12 weeks (Option D): This is beyond the recommended timeframe for post-placental IUD insertion and would require a separate insertion procedure.

questions.text: Until what time after delivery can an Intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) be inserted postpartum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Within 48 hours

Explanation:Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) can be inserted postpartum effectively, preferably within 48 hours of delivery.

  • Immediate post-placental insertion is optimal
  • The 48-hour window allows for safe insertion while the cervix remains dilated
  • This timing aligns with the most preferred timing for postpartum IUCD insertion
  • Early insertion reduces the risk of unintended pregnancy in the postpartum period

Within 24 hours (Option A): While insertion is possible within 24 hours, the safe window extends up to 48 hours, making this timeframe unnecessarily restrictive.

Within 6 weeks (Option C): This represents post-puerperal insertion, which is not the optimal timing for postpartum IUCD placement.

Within 12 weeks (Option D): This extends well beyond the recommended timeframe for postpartum IUCD insertion.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is tandem radiotherapy commonly used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cervical cancer

Explanation:

Tandem radiotherapy is predominantly used in the management of cervical cancer to deliver targeted internal radiation via brachytherapy.

Ovarian Cancer (Option B): Tandem radiotherapy is not commonly used. Treatment typically involves surgery and chemotherapy, with radiation being less common.

Choriocarcinoma (Option C): Tandem radiotherapy is not a standard treatment. Management often includes chemotherapy as the primary mode of treatment.

Endometrial Cancer (Option D): While radiation is used, tandem radiotherapy is not the standard approach. Treatment often involves surgery, and when radiation is used, it's typically EBRT or vaginal brachytherapy without tandems.

Management of Ca cervix

Stage

Criteria

Management

Ia1

<3 mm NO LVSI

Conization or extra fascial hysterectomy

Ia1

<3 mm with LVSI

• Radical trachelectomy

• Or radical hysterectomy + pelvic LAD

• Or SLN

IA2

≥3 mm <5 mm

• Radical trachelectomy

• Or radical hysterectomy + pelvic LAD

• Or SLN

IB1

≥5 mm <2 cm

• Radical trachelectomy

• Or radical hysterectomy + pelvic LAD

• Or SLN

IB2

≥2 cm <4 cm

Radical Hysterectomy + Pelvic LAD

IB3

≥4 cm

Chemoradiation

IIA1

<4 cm + upper vagina

Radical Hysterectomy + Pelvic LAD or Chemoradiation

IIA2

≥4 cm + upper vagina

Chemoradiation

questions.text: A patient visited the outpatient department reporting symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) accompanied by hirsutism. Among the following choices, which one does NOT align with appropriate management strategies for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - OCP alone

  • While OCPs are effective in regulating menstrual cycles and lowering androgen levels, OCPs alone may not be sufficient to fully address hirsutism, especially in cases where symptoms are more pronounced. Most clinical guidelines recommend a combination approach for managing hirsutism, integrating OCPs with antiandrogens or other supportive therapies to achieve better results.

Combining OCPs with metformin (Option C) is effective, particularly for managing insulin resistance and menstrual irregularities, while also addressing hirsutism through the hormonal effects of oral contraceptives (OCPs)

Combining OCP with antiandrogen medications (spironolactone) (Option B) is often recommended when OCPs alone do not sufficiently control hirsutism. Antiandrogens can block the effects of androgens, providing additional benefit

Combining OCP and lifestyle modifications (Option D), including dietary changes, regular exercise, and weight management, are recommended as part of PCOS management. Weight reduction leads to ovulation [in 30% of cases]; loss of even 5-10% weight increases insulin sensitivity and can regularize cycles.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Condyloma acuminata:

  • Condyloma acuminata, also known as genital warts, is a sexually transmitted infection caused by certain strains of human papillomavirus (HPV). It results in the development of soft, fleshy, raised growths in the genital, anal, or oral areas. These growths can vary in size and appearance but often have a cauliflower-like appearance, which matches the description provided in the question.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Condyloma lata: This term is associated with secondary syphilis and refers to flat, broad, wart-like lesions that can occur in the genital area. These lesions are painless and can have a moist appearance. However, the image you mentioned does not correspond to condyloma lata.

Option B - Molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. It leads to the formation of small, dome-shaped papules or nodules on the skin with a central depression. These growths are often painless and can be found in various areas of the body. The image might resemble this condition to some extent, but it's not the correct match.

Option D - None of the Above: This option doesn't seem to be correct in this context, as the image does resemble a specific skin condition.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Microscopy revealed the cell shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bacterial vaginosis:

  • Bacterial vaginosis is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora, resulting in the overgrowth of certain bacteria. One of the key features of BV is the presence of "clue cells." These clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that are coated with bacteria, particularly Gardnerella vaginalis. Clue cells can be identified under a microscope when examining a vaginal discharge sample. The presence of clue cells is a hallmark of bacterial vaginosis and is a key diagnostic feature. BV typically presents with symptoms such as a fishy or unpleasant vaginal odor, thin grayish-white vaginal discharge, and sometimes vaginal itching or discomfort. It is important to diagnose and treat BV to alleviate symptoms and prevent potential complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Herpes: Herpes, caused by the herpes simplex virus, typically presents with painful genital sores or ulcers.

Option B - Candida albicans: Candida albicans is associated with vaginal yeast infections and may result in symptoms like itching, burning, and a thick, white discharge.

Option C - Trichomonas vaginalis: Trichomonas vaginalis is a parasitic infection that can cause vaginal discharge with a foul odor, but it is usually associated with greenish or yellowish discharge and other symptoms like itching and inflammation.

questions.text: A girl presented with irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth in the OPD. USG revealed multiple ovarian follicles. Which of the following would be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Serum testosterone:

  • PCOS is characterized by increased androgen production from the ovaries, leading to symptoms such as irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth (hirsutism).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sex hormone binding globulin levels: SHBG levels are typically decreased. SHBG binds to sex hormones, including testosterone, and regulates their bioavailability. With lower SHBG levels, more testosterone remains free and active in the bloodstream, contributing to the symptoms of hyperandrogenism.

Option C - FSH levels: Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels may be normal or even lower in PCOS.

Option D - FSH/LH ratio: An elevated LH/FSH ratio is a characteristic hormonal pattern in PCOS but not the elevated FSH/LH ratio

questions.text:
What is the wrong match?


	
		
			
			a. Uterine Prolapse
			
			
			1. Hysterectomy
			
		
		
			
			b. Vault prolapse
			
			
			2. Sacrospinous fixation
			
		
		
			
			c. Rectocele
			
			
			3. Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy
			
		
		
			
			d. Cystocele
			
			
			4. Colposuspension
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) d-4

Explanation:

The surgical treatment for cystocele is anterior colporrhaphy and not colposuspension.

 

Cystocele

Clinical features
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Pelvic discomfort
  • Anterior vaginal wall prolapse
  • Bulge shows transverse rugosities and impulse on coughing

Management

Surgical: (recommended for women >40 years)

  • Anterior Colporrhaphy: (most preferred)
    • weakened tissue between the bladder and vagina is repaired.
  • Mesh Repair:
    • synthetic mesh is used for additional support.
    • Risk of recurrence, mesh erosion and infection
  • Sacral Colpopexy:
    • Mesh is attached from the top of the vagina to the sacrum to lift the prolapsed organs.
    • High risk of recurrence and complications
  • Vaginal Hysterectomy:
    • Considered in cases where uterine prolapse coexists with cystocele.

Conservative:

  • Recommended in young women with prolapse following childbirth for the initial 4-6 months
  • Pelvic floor exercises
  • Lifestyle modifications: Avoid heavy lifting and constipation
  • Pessary insertion (in patients unfit for surgery)

 

Hysterectomy (Option A) involves the removal of the uterus and is a common treatment for uterine prolapse, especially when conservative measures fail to provide relief and in women older than 40 years.

Sacrospinous fixation or sacrospinous colpopexy (Option B) can fix the vaginal vault to sacrospinous ligaments. Vault prolapse is a delayed complication of hysterectomy. This is the preferred treatment for vault prolapse.

The surgical treatment of rectocele is posterior colporrhaphy or colpoperineorrhaphy (Option C). Protrusion of the rectum with the posterior vaginal wall is called rectocele.

questions.text: What is the use of the instrument given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Hysterosalpingography

  • The given instrument is The Leech-Wilkinson Intrauterine Cannula which is used in hysterosalpingography. It is a straight instrument with a conical tip. This cone is screwed into the cervix. Then dye is injected.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Myomectomy, sometimes called fibroidectomy, refers to the surgical removal of uterine leiomyomas, also known as fibroids. The instrument used is the Bonney myomectomy clamp.

Option C: Endometrial biopsy is a procedure in which a tissue sample is obtained from the uterus's endometrium (the inside lining) and then observed under a microscope.

Option D: Conization of the cervix or cold knife cone (CKC) is a surgical procedure used to diagnose and treat cervical dysplasia or early cervical cancer. It involves the excision of a cone-shaped portion of the cervix to remove a cervical lesion and the entire transformation zone.

questions.text: In this case, a 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after experiencing bleeding from the vagina, which was preceded by a lack of menstrual periods for 7 weeks. The woman is in a state of hemodynamic shock and has a positive result for serum beta hCG. During the examination, a mass can be felt in the lower abdomen. What is the probable diagnosis in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • The presentation of bleeding per vaginum, preceded by amenorrhea for 7 weeks, along with a positive serum beta hCG, and a palpable mass in the lower abdomen, are all suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy. Ectopic pregnancy is a pregnancy that occurs outside of the uterus, typically in the fallopian tubes. A ruptured ectopic pregnancy can cause hemodynamic shock and requires immediate medical attention. 
  • Some common causes of ectopic pregnancy include: 
  • Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) 
  • Endometriosis Scarring or damage to the fallopian tubes
  •  Previous abdominal or pelvic surgery

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pyelonephritis: This is a type of kidney infection caused by bacteria that have entered the kidneys from the urinary tract. Symptoms may include fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and pain in the back or side. While pyelonephritis can be associated with urinary tract symptoms, it is not typically associated with vaginal bleeding or a palpable mass in the lower abdomen.

Option B - Gastrointestinal stromal tumor: This is a type of tumor that can develop in the digestive tract, usually in the stomach or small intestine. Symptoms may include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Gastrointestinal stromal tumors are rare and not typically associated with vaginal bleeding or a palpable mass in the lower abdomen, making this option unlikely. 

Option C - Red degeneration of fibroid: Fibroids are non-cancerous growths that can develop in the uterus. Red degeneration is a type of fibroid degeneration that can cause pain and vaginal bleeding. However, it is not typically associated with hemodynamic shock or a palpable mass in the lower abdomen.

questions.text: Which demographic is most likely to present with warty lesions on the vulva, along with multiple warty growths around the anal canal, as observed during examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Condyloma accuminata

Explanation:

Condyloma acuminata, also known as anogenital warts, is a sexually transmitted infection caused by certain strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV).

  • It commonly presents as multiple warty growths on the vulva, perianal region, and other areas of the anogenital area.
  • The warts may have a cauliflower-like appearance and can vary in size and number.

Molluscum contagiosum (Option B) is a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV). It typically presents as small, flesh-colored, dome-shaped bumps on the skin. While it can occur in the anogenital area, it is less commonly associated with warty lesions compared to condyloma acuminata.
