Chancroid (Option C) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by painful genital ulcers or sores, rather than warty growths.

Herpes (Option D) is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). It can manifest as genital ulcers or blisters, often accompanied by pain and itching. While herpes can cause vesicular or ulcerative lesions, it is not typically associated with warty growths like condyloma acuminata.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes with chronic vulval itching and pain. On examination, there is a vulval lesion suspicious of vulval cancer. Which of the following lymph node/s should be considered for sentinel node biopsy to look for the metastatic spread?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Superficial inguinal lymph nodes

Explanation:

Superficial inguinal lymph nodes:

  • Vulval cancer primarily drains lymph to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, which are the first-echelon nodes.
  • Sentinel node biopsy in vulval cancer targets these nodes to detect regional metastatic spread early, minimizing the need for extensive lymphadenectomy.

 

Vulval cancer

Age Group

Most common in elderly women, especially in the 6th and 7th decades, (50-70 years age group)

Risk Factors

HPV infections, HSV infections, smoking, chronic immunosuppression, chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., lichen sclerosis).

Histological Type

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common type.

Common Sites
  • Labia majora: Most common site (60%).
  • Clitoris: Second most common site (15%).

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) growth.
  • Ulcerative lesions.

Symptoms
  • Pruritus (most common), often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Swelling, lump, or ulcer.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain (late symptom).

Spread
  • Primarily through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • Commonly involved lymph nodes: Inguinofemoral.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly impacts prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy: Preferred for lesions < 1 cm, for histological assessment of invasion depth.
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm.
  • Wedge biopsy, Keyes punch biopsy, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (to assess inguinofemoral node involvement).

Treatment
  • Vulvectomy: Partial or total, depending on disease stage.
  • Inguinal lymph node dissection: To evaluate disease spread.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy (Superficial inguinal lymph nodes): Determines stage and prognosis.

 

Pelvic lymph nodes (Option A) are involved in later stages of vulval cancer. They are not first-line nodes for sentinel biopsy.

Cloquet node (Rosenmüller node) (Option B) is a deep inguinal node, located near the femoral canal, may be involved in advanced disease but is not routinely targeted in sentinel node biopsy.

Deep inguinal lymph nodes (Option D) are Though involved in advanced vulval cancer, these nodes are downstream of the superficial inguinal nodes and are not sentinel nodes.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman who has never given birth and is undergoing hormone replacement therapy (HRT) presents with abdominal pain. On examination, a non-painful palpable mass is detected in the right adnexa. Following further investigation, she undergoes laparotomy, and her ovaries are observed as described. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ovarian carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Ovarian carcinoma is a common cause of adnexal masses in postmenopausal women.
  • The patient’s history of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and a non-tender right adnexal mass raise suspicion, as HRT may stimulate tumor growth and increase the risk of ovarian carcinoma in postmenopausal women.


“Nodular carcinoma of ovary” (Option A) is not a recognized medical term or specific diagnosis. It might be used to describe a solid tumor, but it is not a common or accurate term to describe ovarian malignancy. Ovarian carcinoma is the preferred and more precise diagnosis for malignant ovarian tumors in this context.

A chocolate cyst (endometrioma) (Option B) is an ovarian cyst filled with old blood, typically associated with endometriosis. This condition is more common in premenopausal women. In postmenopausal women, especially those on HRT, ovarian carcinoma is more likely, as hormonal therapy can influence the growth of ovarian tumors.

Ovarian fibroids (Option C) are not a recognized medical entity. Fibroids, or leiomyomas, are smooth muscle tumors that occur in the uterus, not the ovaries. A mass in the adnexa that is associated with a postmenopausal woman, especially with HRT use, is more consistent with ovarian carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the preferred diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:
Option B. Cystoscopy: This option is correct.

The investigation of choice for vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a cystoscopy.

A vesicovaginal fistula is an abnormal connection between the bladder and the vagina, leading to the passage of urine from the bladder into the vagina. To diagnose and evaluate a vesicovaginal fistula, a cystoscopy is typically performed. During a cystoscopy, a thin, flexible tube with a camera (cystoscope) is inserted through the urethra and into the bladder. This allows the healthcare provider to directly visualize the interior of the bladder and identify any abnormal openings or connections.

Incorrect option:

Option A. IVP (Intravenous Pyelogram): This option is incorrect. An IVP is an imaging test that involves injecting a contrast dye into the bloodstream to visualize the urinary tract, including the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. While an IVP can help detect abnormalities in the urinary system, it is not the investigation of choice for diagnosing a vesicovaginal fistula.

Option C. 3 Swab Test: This option is Not correct. The "3 Swab Test" is a not diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula.

OptionD. X-ray: This option is incorrect. X-rays are not the investigation of choice for diagnosing a vesicovaginal fistula. While certain X-ray techniques, such as a retrograde urethrogram, may be used to evaluate urinary tract abnormalities, they are not specific or sensitive enough for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistulas.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common organism causing pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option D: Chlamydia

  • Chlamydia trachomatis: Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common organism causing pelvic inflammatory disease. It is a sexually transmitted infection that can ascend from the lower genital tract to the upper reproductive organs, leading to inflammation and infection. Chlamydia trachomatis is responsible for a significant number of cases of PID.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Gardnerella vaginalis: Gardnerella vaginalis is associated with bacterial vaginosis, which is a condition characterized by an imbalance of vaginal bacteria. While bacterial vaginosis can increase the risk of developing PID, Gardnerella vaginalis is not the primary causative organism for PID.

Option B: Bacteroids: Bacteroids are a group of anaerobic bacteria that are commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract. They are not typically associated with the development of PID.

Option C: Neisseria gonorrhoeae: While Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common sexually transmitted infection, it is not the most common organism causing PID. However, it can be a significant cause of PID in some cases.

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady presented with complaint of postcoital bleeding. On per speculum examination, the following is seen. It bleeds on touch. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cervical polyp:

  • Cervical polyps can present with postcoital bleeding, and they often bleed on touch. They are typically visible during a per speculum examination.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cervical fibroid: Cervical fibroids are not common. Fibroids are more commonly found in the uterus itself.

Option C - Cervical carcinoma: While cervical carcinoma can cause postcoital bleeding, the presence of a visible cervical polyp is more indicative of a benign condition.

Option D - Hemorrhagic cyst: Hemorrhagic cysts are more related to the ovaries and are not typically visualized during a per speculum examination.

In summary, the possible diagnosis based on the presentation of postcoital bleeding with a visible cervical polyp that bleeds on touch is Cervical polyp (Option B).

questions.text: A 14-year-old presents with cyclical abdominal pain and has not attained menarche yet. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Imperforate hymen:

  • An imperforate hymen can present with cyclical abdominal pain in a young girl who has not attained menarche. The accumulation of menstrual blood behind the imperforate hymen causes pain.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Prolapse: Prolapse typically refers to the descent or falling out of organs, such as the uterus or bladder. It is not consistent with the presented symptoms and image.

Option C - Tumor: While tumors can cause abdominal pain, an imperforate hymen is a more likely explanation for the symptoms described in a pre-menarchal girl.

Option D - None of the above: The symptoms and image are indicative of a specific condition, so "None of the above" is not the correct choice.

In summary, based on the presentation of cyclical abdominal pain in a 14-year-old girl who has not attained menarche, the likely diagnosis is Imperforate hymen (Option A).

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for Trichomonas vaginalis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B.

  • Metronidazole is the treatment of choice for Trichomonas vaginalis, a common sexually transmitted infection caused by the Trichomonas parasite. Metronidazole effectively kills the parasite and helps resolve the infection.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Amikacin: Amikacin is an antibiotic primarily used for the treatment of certain bacterial infections. It is not effective against Trichomonas vaginalis.

Option C. Chloramphenicol: Chloramphenicol is an antibiotic used to treat certain bacterial infections. It is not effective against Trichomonas vaginalis.

Option D. Ampicillin: Ampicillin is an antibiotic primarily used for the treatment of bacterial infections. It is not effective against Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an irreversible method of contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A

  • Laparoscopic tubal ligation: Laparoscopic tubal ligation, commonly known as "getting your tubes tied," is a surgical procedure that permanently blocks or seals the fallopian tubes. It is considered an irreversible method of contraception because it creates a physical barrier that prevents sperm from reaching the egg, thus eliminating the possibility of fertilization and pregnancy. Once the fallopian tubes are ligated or blocked, it is generally not reversible, although some rare cases of successful tubal ligation reversal have been reported.

Incorrect Option:

Option B. Copper-T: Copper-T, also known as intrauterine device (IUD), is a long-acting reversible contraceptive method. It is a small T-shaped device that is inserted into the uterus to prevent pregnancy. Copper-T works by releasing copper ions, which create an environment that is toxic to sperm, thus preventing fertilization. While Copper-T provides long-term contraception, it is a reversible method. It can be removed at any time if the individual wishes to become pregnant.

Option C. Implanon: Implanon, also known as a contraceptive implant, is a small rod-shaped device that is inserted under the skin of the upper arm. It releases a synthetic hormone called etonogestrel, which prevents ovulation and thickens cervical mucus, making it difficult for sperm to reach the egg. Implanon provides long-term contraception but is also reversible. It can be removed, and fertility can return to normal.

Option D. LNG-IUD: LNG-IUD, or levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device, is another type of intrauterine device that releases a progestin hormone called levonorgestrel. It works by thickening cervical mucus, thinning the uterine lining, and inhibiting sperm movement. Like Copper-T and Implanon, LNG-IUD is a reversible method of contraception. It can be removed, and fertility can be restored.

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with painless vaginal bleeding. She has no history of hormone replacement therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endometrial carcinoma

Explanation: Postmenopausal bleeding (PMB) is the most common presenting symptom of malignancy, and any PMB should be considered carcinoma until proven otherwise.

Postmenopausal bleeding (PMB) is defined as vaginal bleeding that occurs 12 months or more after the cessation of menstruation.

Endometrial Carcinoma

Risk factors

Protective factors

  • Age (>50 yrs)
  • Obesity
  • Estrogen exposure
  • Nulliparity
  • Tamoxifen
  • Family history
    • LYNCH syndrome
    • BRCA1 & BRCA2 mutations
  • Diabetes
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  • Early menarche
  • Late menopause
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pregnancy and childbirth
  • Regular exercise
  • Healthy weight management
  • LNG-IUS

Adenomyosis (Option B): Typically affects women of reproductive age and presents with dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and a tender, bulky uterus & not postmenopausal bleeding.

Uterine fibroid (Option C): Usually causes heavy menstrual bleeding during reproductive years; postmenopausal fibroids typically shrink and rarely cause bleeding unless degenerating.

Endometriosis (Option D): Disease of reproductive-age women associated with pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and infertility & not a cause of PMB.

questions.text: A cut section of the uterus shows a growth arising from the endometrium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Carcinoma endometrium

Explanation: The image depicts Carcinoma endometrium as the question specifically states that the growth arises from the endometrium.

  • Carcinoma endometrium typically appears as an irregular, friable, or polypoidal mass projecting into the endometrial cavity on gross pathology.
  • It originates from the endometrial lining and may invade the myometrium with progression.

Adenomyosis (Option B): Involves endometrial tissue within the myometrium, leading to diffuse uterine enlargement and trabeculated cut surface.

Endometriosis (Option C): Endometrial glands/stroma located outside the uterus, often on ovaries, peritoneum & does not present as intrauterine growth.

Fibroid uterus (Option D): Benign smooth muscle tumor (leiomyoma) usually arises from the myometrium, appearing as a firm, whorled mass & not from the endometrial lining.

questions.text: All of the following are Hyperestrogenic conditions except.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Low BMI:

  • Low body mass index (BMI) is not typically associated with hyperestrogenic conditions. In fact, higher body fat levels can lead to increased estrogen production. Low BMI might be associated with lower estrogen levels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ovarian cancer: Ovarian cancer can lead to hyperestrogenic conditions. Ovarian tumors can produce excess estrogen, contributing to hyperestrogenism.

Option C - Use of Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is a medication often used in the treatment of breast cancer. It acts as an estrogen receptor antagonist in breast tissue, which can lead to increased estrogen levels in other tissues due to a feedback mechanism.

Option D - Endometriosis: Endometriosis is a condition where tissue similar to the lining of the uterus grows outside the uterus. This extra tissue can produce estrogen and lead to hyperestrogenic conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis if the middle swab is stained with Dye in Methylene Blue-3 swab test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -Vesicovaginal Fistula:

  • If the middle swab is stained with dye in the Methylene Blue-3 swab test, it indicates that the dye has travelled from the bladder into the vagina, confirming the presence of a vesicovaginal fistula.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Urethrovaginal Fistula: The Methylene Blue-3 swab test primarily assesses connections involving the bladder, and since the urethra is separate from the bladder, this test is less likely to detect urethrovaginal fistulas.

Option C -Uretero-vaginal Fistula: Methylene Blue-3 swab test is focused on the bladder, so it is not typically used to diagnose uretero-vaginal fistulas.

Option D -All above: While it's important to consider different types of fistulas, the Methylene Blue-3 swab test is specifically designed to diagnose vesicovaginal fistulas. Therefore, staining of the middle swab with dye would not directly indicate the presence of urethrovaginal or uretero-vaginal fistulas.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones are secreted by sertoli cells and Leydig cells respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D-Inhibin and testosterone:

  • Sertoli cells are in the seminiferous tubules of the testes and play a crucial role in supporting the development and maturation of sperm cells (spermatogenesis). They secrete a hormone called inhibin.
  • Leydig cells, also known as interstitial cells, are found in the connective tissue of the testes. They are responsible for producing and secreting testosterone, a primary male sex hormone.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - DHA and testosterone: DHA (Docosahexaenoic acid) is an omega-3 fatty acid and not a hormone. It is important for brain and eye health. Testosterone is secreted by leydig cells. 

Option B - Testosterone and inhibin: Sertoli cells do not secrete testosterone they secrete inhibin and leydig cells secrete testosterone, not inhibin. 

Option C - Testosterone and DHA: Sertoli cells do not secrete testosterone they secrete inhibin. DHA (Docosahexaenoic acid) is an omega-3 fatty acid and not a hormone. It is important for brain and eye health.

questions.text: Which of the following is studied in PCOD?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Serum testosterone level:

  • PCOS is often associated with elevated levels of androgens, including testosterone, in the blood. Measuring serum testosterone levels is one of the diagnostic criteria for PCOS, as high levels of androgens contribute to the symptoms and complications associated with the condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Urine study: While urine tests might be performed as part of a comprehensive health assessment, they are not specific to diagnosing PCOS.

Option B - Sleep study: Sleep studies, also known as polysomnography, are not directly related to the diagnosis of PCOS. There is no direct link between sleep studies and PCOS diagnosis.

Option D - Both A & B: This option is not the correct answer. Neither urine study nor sleep study are commonly used for diagnosing PCOS, as explained above.

questions.text: Male infertility is diagnosed with karyotype 47 XXY. Which of the following statement is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Decreased FSH:

  • In individuals with Klinefelter syndrome (47 XXY), there is typically an increased level of FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) rather than a decreased level.
  • Klinefelter syndrome is associated with primary testicular failure, leading to inadequate testosterone production. In response to the low testosterone levels, the pituitary gland releases more FSH and LH (Luteinizing Hormone) in an attempt to stimulate the testes to produce more testosterone.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hyalinization of seminiferous tubules: One of the characteristic histopathological findings in individuals with Klinefelter syndrome is the hyalinization of seminiferous tubules.

Option C - Decreased testis size: Men with Klinefelter syndrome often have smaller testes (testicular atrophy) compared to individuals with a normal chromosomal composition (46 XY).

Option D - Azoospermia: Azoospermia refers to the absence of sperm in the ejaculate. It is a common finding in individuals with Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is treated with McCall’s Culdoplasty?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Enterocele:

  • McCall's culdoplasty is a surgical procedure used to repair an enterocele. An enterocele is a type of pelvic organ prolapse where the small intestine bulges into the vaginal space.
  • McCall's culdoplasty involves attaching the vaginal cuff (the upper part of the vagina) to the back of the cervix or the uterosacral ligaments, creating support and preventing the prolapse of the small intestine into the vaginal space.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ureterocele: McCall's culdoplasty is not typically performed to address a ureterocele. Treatment for a ureterocele usually involves surgical intervention aimed at relieving urinary obstruction and preventing infection.

Option C - Cystocele: While McCall's culdoplasty can be used to repair a cystocele indirectly by providing support to the vaginal cuff, it is primarily associated with the repair of enteroceles.

Option D - Both A & C: This option is not accurate because McCall's culdoplasty is specifically performed to address enteroceles (option A) rather than cystoceles (option C).

questions.text: Sperm count on a seminormal is 16 million/ml, with 40% motility and <1% of sperm with normal morphology. What is the term for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Teratospermia:

  • Teratospermia refers to a condition where a significant percentage of sperm in a semen sample have abnormal morphology (shape and structure). In this case, the semen sample has less than 1% of sperm with normal morphology, which aligns with the definition of teratospermia

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oligospermia: Oligospermia refers to a condition where the sperm count in a semen sample is lower than the normal range. In this case, the sperm count is 16 million/ml, which is within the normal range, so oligospermia is not the correct term.

Option B - Normospermia: Normospermia refers to a situation where the sperm parameters, including count, motility, and morphology, are within the normal ranges. While the sperm count of 16 million/ml is within the normal range, the low motility and abnormal morphology disqualify this option.

Option C - Asthenospermia: Asthenospermia is a condition characterized by reduced sperm motility. In this case, the motility is 40%, which is lower than the normal range. However, the primary issue here is the abnormal morphology, so asthenospermia is not the correct term.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents with infertility and respiratory infections. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia:

  • Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a genetic disorder that affects the function of cilia, which are hair-like structures present on the surface of cells. Cilia play a crucial role in the movement of mucus and fluids in various parts of the body, including the respiratory tract.
  • In individuals with PCD, the cilia do not function properly, leading to respiratory problems such as chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and recurrent respiratory infections. Additionally, impaired ciliary function can affect fertility in males due to issues with sperm motility.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Akinesia: Akinesia is the absence of movement. A person with akinesia cannot move their muscles, even if they try.

Option C - Tardive Dyskinesia: Tardive dyskinesia is a condition characterized by involuntary and repetitive movements of the face and other body parts, often caused by long-term use of certain medications that affect dopamine receptors. It is not related to the symptoms of infertility and respiratory infections described in the case.

Option D - Athetosis: Athetosis is a movement disorder characterized by slow, involuntary, and writhing movements of the limbs and other body parts. It is typically associated with damage to the basal ganglia in the brain and is not relevant to the symptoms of the patient in the case.

questions.text: Identify the hormone present in the contraceptive shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Nonoxynol 9

  • Today is a spermicidal contraceptive. It contains nonoxynol-9, which breaks the outer covering of sperms and kills them, thereby preventing pregnancy.
  • Nonoxynol-9 is a vaginal spermicide used for non-hormonal contraception in conjunction with other modes of contraception. 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: These are not present in Today's formulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the IUCD with the longest lifespan?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: CuT 380 A

  • CuT 380 A is a copper-carrying intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD).
  • CuT has the highest life span of 10 years.
  •  It does not require replacement for long periods and does not interfere with sexual activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Progestasert is a T-shaped device containing progesterone. The hormone released in the uterus forms a thick plug of mucus at the cervical os, which prevents penetration by the sperm and thus exerts an added contraceptive effect. It is expensive and requires yearly replacement.

Option C: Mirena contains LNG and can be retained for 5 years. It is a type of hormone-containing IUD that combines the best properties of IUD and hormonal contraceptives.

Option D: Nova T is a Cu-containing IUD with silver added to the copper wire, thereby increasing its lifespan to 5 years.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman complained of inability to conceive, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain. She has a history of frequent episodes of pelvic inflammatory disease. Hysterosalpingogram shows an absence of peritoneal spillage on the right side. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Tubal block

  • A blocked fallopian tube, or tubal factor infertility, occurs when an obstruction, such as scarring, an adhesion, or infection, prevents the ovum from traveling down the tube.
  • This patient's history of frequent PID, combined with a lack of peritoneal spill of contrast on HSG, indicates a diagnosis of unilateral tubal blockage.
  • Other tests for tubal patency:
    • Laparoscopic chromotubation
    • Sonosalpingography (SSG)
    • Hysteroscopy and falloscopy.
    • Ampullary and fimbrial salpingoscopy

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Endometriosis is the occurrence of ectopic benign endometrial tissues outside the uterus cavity. Endometriosis is not well visualized on HSG.

Option C: Asherman Syndrome (intrauterine adhesions or intrauterine synechiae) occurs when scar tissue forms inside the uterus and/or the cervix. These adhesions occur after surgery of the uterus or after a dilatation and curettage with tuberculosis. On HSG, there are multiple irregular linear filling defects (may give a lacunar pattern), with the inability to appropriately distend the endometrial cavity.

Option D: Bilateral hydrosalpinx is a condition where fluid accumulates in both fallopian tubes, creating blockages. HSG will classically show dilated fallopian tubes, filling with contrast and with absence of free spillage.

questions.text: Which corrective procedure yields the most favorable obstetric outcome for a 24-year-old woman who visits the infertility clinic due to recurrent abortions and is diagnosed with a septate uterus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • Transcervical septum resection is considered best as it avoids a uterine scar and elective cesarean section needs. The septum is resected with a resectoscope or scissors.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Jones Metroplasty is a type of metroplasty that has an abdominal approach which causes uterine scarring.

Option B: Strassmann metroplasty is a type of metroplasty that  has an abdominal approach which causes uterine scarring.

Option C: Tompkins metroplasty is a type of metroplasty that  has an abdominal approach which causes uterine scarring.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • It is a case of Asherman Syndrome. Intrauterine adhesions are typically seen on HSG as multiple irregular linear filling defects (may give a lacunar pattern), with the inability to distend the endometrial cavity appropriately.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Sheehan's syndrome (SS) is postpartum hypopituitarism caused by necrosis of the pituitary gland

Option B: Endometriosis is the occurrence of ectopic benign endometrial tissues outside the uterus cavity. Endometriosis is not well seen on the X-ray or the ultrasound version of the HSG.

Option D: Pyometra is a serious, life-threatening infection within the uterus. It is typically caused by anaerobic bacteria growth within a poorly draining uterus.

questions.text: Identify the fistula labelled in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:

  • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is an abnormal opening between the bladder and the vagina that results in continuous and unremitting urinary incontinence.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Vesicocervical Fistula is a rare type of urogenital fistula and is usually due to urinary bladder injury, which can occur during cesarean section due to its proximity to the uterus

Option B: Urethrovaginal Fistula is an abnormal passageway that may occur in the urethra and the vagina. It is a subset of vaginal fistulas. It can occur as an obstetrical complication, catheter insertion injury, or a surgical injury

Option C: Ureterovaginal Fistula is an abnormal passageway existing between the ureter and the vagina. It presents as urinary incontinence.

questions.text: In cases of genital tuberculosis, which segment of the fallopian tube is frequently affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • In the female genital tract, fallopian tubes are always the first to be involved in genital tuberculosis. The disease is commonly bilateral in distribution.
  • It affects the ampulla of the fallopian tube.

questions.text: What is the most frequently occurring benign tumor of the ovaries that affects both sides in women of reproductive age?
questions.solution:
Correct option B. Follicular cysts

Explanation:

Follicular cysts, also known as functional ovarian cysts, are the most frequently occurring benign tumors of the ovaries in women of reproductive age. These cysts form as a result of the menstrual cycle and typically resolve on their own without treatment.

The other options are incorrect because:

Option A. Epithelial cell tumor: Epithelial cell tumors of the ovaries are common, but they are more likely to be malignant rather than benign.

Option C. Sex cord stromal tumor: Sex cord stromal tumors, which include granulosa cell tumors and fibromas, are relatively rare ovarian tumors. They can be benign or malignant, but they are not the most frequently occurring benign tumors.

Option D. Benign teratoma: Benign teratomas, also known as dermoid cysts, are common ovarian tumors, but they often contain a mixture of tissues derived from different germ cell layers, including skin, hair, teeth, and other structures. They are typically found in younger women and are often unilateral.

questions.text: What measures can be taken to decrease the likelihood of endometrial cancer in a postmenopausal woman undergoing hormone replacement therapy (HRT)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Adding progesterone to estrogen

Explanation:

  • Estrogen is a hormone that plays a critical role in the growth and development of the female reproductive system. It is responsible for thickening and maintaining the lining of the uterus, or endometrium, during the menstrual cycle.
  • In postmenopausal women, the levels of estrogen decrease significantly, leading to thinning of the endometrium.    
  • However, if postmenopausal women take estrogen-only hormone therapy, it can stimulate the growth of the endometrial lining, which can increase the risk of endometrial cancer. This is because the constant exposure to estrogen can cause the endometrial cells to divide and multiply rapidly, leading to the development of abnormal cells that can become cancerous.
  • Adding progesterone to the hormone therapy can counteract this effect by balancing the growth-promoting effects of estrogen on the endometrium. In postmenopausal women, progesterone can help to thin the endometrial lining and reduce the risk of endometrial cancer. Combined with estrogen, it is referred to as hormone replacement therapy (HRT).

Incorrect Options:

Combined oral contraceptive pills (Option A) : While combined oral contraceptive pills contain both estrogen and progestin, they are not typically used to reduce the risk of endometrial cancer in postmenopausal women as they have different concentrations of progesterone and estrogen. 

Clonidine (Option B):  Clonidine is a medication used to treat high blood pressure but is not typically used to reduce the risk of endometrial cancer. Clonidine works by relaxing blood vessels, lowering blood pressure, and reducing the heart rate. Clonidine is not associated with any significant reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

Vitamin E (Option C): While vitamin E is an antioxidant that may have some health benefits. It is found in many foods, including nuts, seeds, fruits and vegetables, and is also available in supplement form. Vitamin E has not been shown to have a significant effect on the risk of endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia and infertility. A diagnosis of endometriosis was made, and she was posted for laparoscopic surgery. During the procedure, dense pelvic adhesions were seen with the bowel stuck to the fundus and cystic ovaries stuck to each other. What is the next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge

questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • Cystectomy involves removing cysts that have formed on the ovaries, while adhesiolysis involves breaking down adhesions that have formed between organs in the pelvic region. This is a common surgical treatment for endometriosis, and it can help to alleviate symptoms and improve fertility in some patients. This would involve removing the ovarian cysts and breaking down the adhesions that are causing the organs to stick together. This can often help to alleviate the patient's symptoms and improve their chances of conceiving if they are trying to get pregnant.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - LUNA for chronic pelvic pain: Laparoscopic uterine nerve ablation (LUNA) is a surgical procedure that involves cutting nerves in the uterus to relieve chronic pelvic pain. However, LUNA is not typically used for the treatment of endometriosis, and it may not be effective for all patients. 

Option B - Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge: Gestrinone is a synthetic hormone that can help to reduce the production of luteinizing hormone (LH), which can trigger ovulation and lead to the growth of endometrial tissue. However, this medication is not typically used as a first-line treatment for endometriosis, and it may not be effective for all patients.

Option D - Hysterectomy and oophorectomy: Hysterectomy involves removing the uterus, while oophorectomy involves removing the ovaries. This is a more drastic treatment option that is typically reserved for patients with severe endometriosis who have not responded to other treatments, or for those who no longer wish to have children

questions.text: Postmenopausal bleeding is most commonly caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- cervical cancer:

  • MC cause of PMB in India: (MC presentation of Ca cervix , however, is post coital bleeding)
  •  MC cause of post menopausal bleeding: Ca cervix
  •  MC cause of PMB in the world: ca cervix

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B (Decubitus Ulcer): Decubitus ulcers, also known as pressure sores or bedsores, are not a common cause of postmenopausal bleeding. These ulcers occur due to prolonged pressure on the skin and are unrelated to postmenopausal bleeding.

  • Option C (Tubercular Endometritis): Tubercular endometritis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, can lead to chronic inflammation of the endometrium and may cause abnormal uterine bleeding. However, it is not the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding worldwide.

  • Option D (Hormone Replacement Therapy): Hormone replacement therapy (HRT), especially estrogen-alone therapy (unopposed estrogen), can cause postmenopausal bleeding. While this is a recognized cause, senile endometrial atrophy is more prevalent and commonly seen in postmenopausal women.

questions.text: A patient with unilateral breast cancer is started on tamoxifen. This will increase the risk of which of the following?

choices.text: Breast cancer in the opposite breast

questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Tamoxifen is a medication that is commonly used in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. While tamoxifen can be effective in reducing the risk of breast cancer recurrence, it does have the potential to increase the risk of certain other types of cancer. One of the most significant risks associated with tamoxifen use is an increased risk of endometrial cancer. This is because tamoxifen acts as an estrogen antagonist in the breast tissue but acts as an estrogen agonist in the uterus, which can lead to abnormal growth of the uterine lining.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Ovarian cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the ovaries, which are the female reproductive organs that produce eggs. Tamoxifen use is not associated with an increased risk of ovarian cancer. However, women with a BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation may be at increased risk for both ovarian and breast cancer, and tamoxifen use may be recommended as a preventive measure.

Option C:  Tamoxifen use is actually used to reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence in the same breast or the opposite breast in women with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. Women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer in one breast may be at increased risk for developing breast cancer in the other breast, and tamoxifen can help reduce that risk.

Option D: Tamoxifen use is not associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer. However, regular cervical cancer screening is still important for all women, including those taking tamoxifen.

questions.text: What is the best recommended management in a case of vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • The best-recommended management for a case of vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele depends on a number of factors, including the severity of the prolapse, the patient's symptoms, and their overall health. However, option C - both anterior colporrhaphy and posterior colpoperineorrhaphy - is a common surgical approach that is often recommended for cases of vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele. Anterior colporrhaphy involves the repair of the anterior vaginal wall to correct a cystocele, while posterior colpoperineorrhaphy involves the repair of the posterior vaginal wall to correct a rectocele. These procedures are often performed together to address both the cystocele and rectocele and provide support to the vaginal vault.

Incorrect Options:

Option A:  Anterior colporrhaphy is a surgical procedure that is used to repair a cystocele or bladder prolapse only.

Option B: Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy is a surgical procedure that is used to repair a rectocele or rectal prolapse only. 

Option D: Hysterectomy is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of the uterus. It may be recommended as a treatment option for a vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele if other treatments have failed or if there are other medical indications for the procedure, such as uterine cancer or endometriosis.

questions.text: The highest incidence of ureteric injury is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Wertheim’s hysterectomy is also called Radical hysterectomy. Following this procedure, bladder atony or dysfunction is one of the known complications. It occurs due to damage to the ureters during surgery. It can also occur due to the damage or division of the sacral connection of the uterovaginal plexus that supplies the urinary bladder and urethra. In such cases, urinary catheterization is done and the bladder is drained continuously for a period of 6-10 days.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vaginal hysterectomy: Vaginal hysterectomy rarely causes ureteric injury. Even though the postoperative complications are less, some immediate complications of vaginal hysterectomy include vault cellulitis, pelvic abscess, thrombophlebitis, pulmonary embolism. Late complication of vaginal hysterectomy is vault prolapse.

Option C -  Abdominal hysterectomy: Postoperative complications are high in case of abdominal hysterectomy. Some immediate complications include hemorrhagic shock, urinary retention due to pain/spasm, and cystitis. Some late complications include overflow incontinence, fever due to peritonitis, cystitis, vault cellulitis, pneumonia, abdominal wound infections, or vascular complications like DVT, phlebitis, intestinal obstruction, pulmonary embolism, hemorrhage, and hematomas. 

Option D - Emergency caesarean sections: Ureteral injury in cesarean sections are rare. However, it can occur while controlling bleeding from lateral extensions. Other intraoperative complications of cesarean section include uterine lacerations, extension of uterine incision, gastrointestinal tract injury, hemorrhage, bladder injury. Some postoperative complications include postpartum hemorrhage, shock, infections, DVT, wound complications, incisional hernia, menstrual irregularities, scar rupture, intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: In the menstrual cycle, which phase is characterized by the presence of vacuolation as a histological feature?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • In the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle, there is involvement of both estrogen and progesterone which are released from the corpus luteum following ovulation. It begins from the 15th day and stops 5-6 days before menstruation. The glands increase in size, the surface epithelium turns more ciliated and columnar. Due to the secretion of glycogen between the basement membrane and nuclei, vacuoles are visualized. This is called SUBNUCLEAR VACUOLATION which is the earliest sign of progesterone effect (appears within 36-48 hours) and persists till the 21st day of cycle. Glands become corkscrew shaped. Marked spiralling of blood vessels are seen. Thickness of the endometrium is highest.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Proliferative phase: Starts from the 5th or 6th day till the 14 day. In this phase, there is rise in estrogen levels which makes the glands tubular, epithelium becomes columnar. Stromal cells become spindle shaped. Spiral vessels extend without giving out any branches below the epithelium. 

Option C - Menstrual phase: During this phase, there is a fall in the levels of estrogen and progesterone due to the regression of corpus luteum which result in the shedding of the endometrium prepared for a pregnancy.

Option D: Subnuclear vacuolation is a histological finding only observed in the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle. There is another phase called the Regenerative phase which starts before the menstruation ends and stops 2-3 days after the end of menstruation. New blood vessels grow from the stump of old ones.

questions.text: In a 55-year-old woman experiencing post-menopausal bleeding, which investigation is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • During postmenopausal period, endometrial biopsy is mandatory to rule out endometrial carcinoma. It is a well-tolerated and less invasive procedure with minimal complications and is done as an outpatient procedure. Endometrial thickness of more than 4-5 mm on TVS is ,endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.
  • Post-menopausal bleeding is considered abnormal and requires thorough evaluation to rule out underlying pathology, especially endometrial cancer. Endometrial biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure that allows the collection of a sample of the endometrial tissue for examination, providing valuable information about the presence of cancer or other abnormalities.

Incorrect Options:

Option A -Ultrasound : Ultrasound is often performed initially to evaluate the thickness of the endometrial lining. If the lining appears thickened, further evaluation, such as an endometrial biopsy, is typically warranted.

Option C - Fractional curettage: Fractional curettage is a more invasive procedure which is done under general anesthesia. It is preferred in case of any suspicion of cancer or when endometrial biopsy is inconclusive or cannot be obtained, in cases of cervical stenosis.

Option D - CA-125: Is a tumor marker used to closely monitor the progression and treatment of ovarian epithelial tumors. It is also elevated in endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometriosis, uterine fibroids, breast lung, pancreas or liver carcinomas. However, it cannot be used as a routine screening tool for the general crowd due to the reduced specificity and sensitivity.

questions.text: A nulliparous lady with a BMI of 23, presents with hirsutism. Ultrasonography was done and an image of the same is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • In PCOS, there is elevated androgen secretion by the ovaries which result in hirsutism (male pattern hair growth), hyperinsulinemia, hyperprolactinemia. The given ultrasound shows an enlarged ovary with multiple cysts peripherally arranged which suggests polycystic ovarian syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Tubal block is usually visualized by hysterosalpingogram (HSG). A few causes are salpingitis, benign polyps within the lumen of the tube, tubal endometriosis, tubal spasm and intratubal mucous debris.

Option C: In Multiple fibroids, transvaginal sonograms show enlarged, distorted uterus homogeneous echogenic areas over the fibroid. Majority are asymptomatic, however a few experience menstrual abnormality, dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia, pressure symptoms, recurrent miscarriage, pelvic or lower abdominal pain.

Option D: In mesenteritis, ultrasound shows thickened and distorted appearance of the root of mesentery with a halo of sparing surrounding the vessels. Most common symptoms of mesenteritis are fever, abdominal pain, and features of intestinal obstruction may also be present. In some cases, abdominal mass can be felt.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about radiotherapy for a 52-year-old woman diagnosed with stage 2B cervical carcinoma is incorrect?

choices.text: Point B is 3 cm lateral to point A
Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the interna uterine canal
Point A receive a dose of 7000 cGy
Point B received a dose of 6000 cGy

questions.solution:
Option B. Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal.

Explanation:

In the standard radiotherapy protocol for cervical carcinoma, Point A is defined as 2 cm above the external os and 2 cm lateral to the junction of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina, not 5 cm lateral. Point B is 3 cm lateral to Point A. These points are crucial in radiation therapy planning for cervical cancer to ensure accurate delivery of radiation to the affected area while sparing surrounding healthy tissues.

Therefore, option b is incorrect because Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 2 cm lateral to the junction of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina, not 5 cm lateral.

questions.text: A 75 year old woman with complaints of mass per vaginum, as shown in the below image was posted for operative repair. During the pre-anaesthetic check-up, she was found to be unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • Le fort’s repair involves the closure of the anterior and posterior vaginal wall followed by approximation using chromic catgut sutures. This procedure is ideally indicated in elderly women who have severe pelvic organ prolapse, who is unfit for longer duration of surgery, and those who are no longer sexually active. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Abdominal wall cervicopexy: Also called as sling operation is indicated in nulliparous or congenital prolapse without cystocele where the cervix is pulled up through abdominal route. A sling is placed anchoring to the anterior abdominal wall and sacrum to provide support to the prolapsed pelvic organs.

Option B - Shirodkar’s sling operation: Also called as anterior colporrhaphy. It is indicated in young women < 40 years of age who are desirous of retaining their childbearing functions. The cervix is not amputated instead it is fixed to the lumbo-sacral fascia using a Mersilene tape, hence pregnancy complications are avoided.

Option D -  Khanna’s sling operation: A mesh sling is placed under the neck of the uterus and is attached to the pubic bone on both sides. The sling supports the mackenrodt’s ligaments. It is similarly indicated in women with grade 2 or grade 3 uterine prolapse who are desirous of retaining their menstrual functions.

questions.text: What is the most suitable treatment for a 55-year-old patient with simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • Simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia has 8% chance of progressing to endometrial malignancy. 
  • In simple hyperplasia the endometrium is thick, glands are dilated with invaginations, dense stroma is present.
  • Atypia indicates that the nuclei of the glands are enlarged, irregular in shape and size, with hyperchromasia indicating a premalignant lesion. In this case, a 55 year old postmenopausal woman with simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia would require a simple hysterectomy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Medroxyprogesterone acetate: Is given in young premenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia. MPA is given 10mg twice daily. Every 3 months, endometrial sampling is done. However, in case of atypical endometrial hyperplasia, hysterectomy is the mainstay of treatment due to the higher risk of invasive cancer.

Option C - Levonorgestrel: Is indicated in young premenopausal women with cystic or adenomatous hyperplasia without atypia. It is given for a period of 6-9 months. Endometrial sampling is done every 6 months.

Option D - Radiotherapy: Is not ideally the first line of treatment in endometrial hyperplasia. However, who are not fit for surgery or those who are not ideal surgical candidates or those who refuse surgery can receive radiotherapy.

questions.text: What is the probable cause of a 14-year-old girl's condition, who has not experienced menarche yet, and presents with cyclic abdominal pain and a hypogastric lump visible during per vaginal examination, along with a bluish swelling?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • The age of the child, chief complaints and examination findings point towards the diagnosis of imperforate hymen. As the child attains 14-16 years of age, menstrual blood gets accumulated in the vagina behind the hymen. Slowly it distends the vagina first, followed by the uterine cavity, and later it distends the fimbrial ends of the fallopian tubes. Imperforate hymen occurs due to the failure of disintegration of the central cells of Mullerian eminence. Vulval inspection may reveal a bluish bulging membrane. The diagnosis can be confirmed by ultrasonography.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bartholin: Bartholin glands two glands that are situated in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora. Infections involving the bartholin gland are usually polymicrobial. Bartholin abscess is associated with fever and unilateral painful swelling beneath the posterior half of labia majora. Bartholin cyst is a unilateral swelling on the posterior half of labia majora which contains glairy colourless fluid.

Option B - Transverse vaginal septum: A thick band of fibrous tissue separates the vagina horizontally into 2 compartments. This produces symptoms similar to imperforate hymen. In majority, the obstructing membrane is often the transverse vaginal septum which lies in close proximity to the inner aspect of the hymen.

Option D - Endometrioma: Endometriosis is a condition where the tissue that lines the uterine endometrium, grows on sites, like ovaries, and fallopian tubes. Endometriomas are ovarian cysts that form due to endometriosis. As the cyst ruptures, tarry, thick fluid (chocolate material) escapes, hence It is also called a chocolate cyst. It occurs in the age group between 30-45 years of age. 70% present with dysmenorrhoea, 40-60% present with infertility, 20-40% present with dyspareunia.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for an 18-year-old girl who has been experiencing low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and amenorrhea for the past six months? During examination, a pelvic mass is detected on the left side, and signs of ascites are evident.
questions.solution:
Correct option D: Genital tuberculosis

  • Considering the age of the child and symptoms like fever, weight loss, 6 month history of amenorrhoea, and examination findings point towards the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis. Genital tuberculosis is seen between 20-40 years of age, which is the child bearing age group. Symptoms include low grade fever, night sweats, anorexia. Amenorrhoea occurs due to the suppression of ovarian functions by the tubercular toxins resulting in oophoritis or due to uterine synechiae formation. On abdominal examination, the abdomen may feel doughy due to matted intestines, free fluid may be present in rare cases and sometimes it can mimic an ovarian cyst. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Submucous fibroid: it produces maximum symptoms like menorrhagia, severe dysmenorrhoea, subfertility, pressure symptoms, recurrent miscarriage, preterm labor, abdominal enlargement..

Option B - Ovarian malignancy: Ovarian malignancy is seen more often in the postmenopausal age group and there is increased association with nulliparity. Symptoms are nonspecific, including abdominal distension, loss of appetite, pelvic pain. As the tumor grows in size, symptoms become more pronounced. 

  • On per vaginal examination, the uterus may be separated from the mass felt per abdomen. 
  • Ascites are often present due to obstruction in the flow of peritoneal fluid through the diaphragm. 
  • Right pleural effusion may also be present.

Option C - Ectopic pregnancy: The fertilized ovum gets implanted and develops outside the normal endometrial cavity. It occurs between 20-30 years of age. 

  • If the diagnosis is ruptured ectopic, symptoms include a short period of amenorrhoea (around 6-8 weeks), colicky type of lower abdominal abdominal pain, vomiting. 
  • Features of shock like pallor, hypotension, cold clammy extremities may be observed. On abdominal examination, no mass is usually felt. 
  • Per vaginal examination may reveal extreme forniceal tenderness or tenderness on movement of the cervix. In unruptured ectopic pregnancy, symptoms like delayed periods or spotting or unilateral flank pain is seen. 
  • On bimanual examination, a pulsatile, small, well circumscribed tender mass can be felt which is felt separate from the uterus.

questions.text: What is the most suitable contraceptive method for a 34-year-old woman who has recently given birth and wishes to prevent pregnancy for the next three years?
questions.solution:
• The most suitable contraceptive method for a 34-year-old woman who has recently given birth and wishes to prevent pregnancy for the next three years is:

    Option B. IUCD with progesterone: Intrauterine Contraceptive Devices (IUCDs) are long-acting and reversible contraceptive methods. They provide effective contraception for several years. There are different types of IUCDs, including those with added progesterone, which can provide additional benefits such as reduced menstrual bleeding and cramps.

    Incorrect Options:

  • Option A. Barrier methods, such as condoms or diaphragms, are effective but might not be the best choice for long-term contraception, especially if the woman wishes to prevent pregnancy for several years.

  • Option C. Injectable progesterone can be an effective contraceptive method, but it requires regular injections, which might not be the most convenient option for every woman.

    Option D. Nothing besides lactation amenorrhea: Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM) is a natural form of contraception that relies on exclusive breastfeeding to prevent ovulation and thus pregnancy. However, it is most effective only in the first six months postpartum, and its effectiveness decreases as the baby starts to consume other foods and supplements in addition to breast milk. Therefore, it might not be a reliable option for three years of contraception.

    Considering the woman's desire for a long-term contraceptive method, Option B (IUCD with progesterone) would be a suitable choice. However, it's essential for her to consult with a healthcare provider to determine the most appropriate method based on her individual health needs and preferences.

questions.text: What should be the treatment for an 8 cm endometrial cyst?
questions.solution:
• Large endometriomas that measure more than 4 cm would require a laparoscopic cystectomy as it may be associated with adhesions to adjacent pelvic structures. It relieves pain. When the normal pelvic anatomy is restored, there is concurrent improvement in fertility. 
  • Pregnancy rates are around 60% in moderate disease and around 35% in severe disease. The cyst is laparoscopically aspirated if the endometrioma is less than 3 cm. The cavity is then irrigated with normal saline.

Incorrect Choices

  • Option a: Needle aspiration: It is done when the endometriomas measure less than 3 cm. The cavity is irrigated with saline; however, in this case scenario, since the endometrioma measures more than 8 cm, needle aspiration would not be recommended.
  • Option c:  GnRH: GnRH analogs reduce the serum estrogen level and simultaneously reduce the growth size. Long-term therapy for more than 6 months is usually not advised. It is not a permanent solution, as the tissue regrows once the treatment is discontinued.
  • Option d: Conservative since asymptomatic: 8 cm endometriomas cannot be managed conservatively as it is often associated with multiple adhesions to the adjacent pelvic structures. Hence, endometriomas of more than 4 cm are subjected to cystectomy.

questions.text: When a congenital heart block is detected in a fetus, which of the following conditions would you need to assess in the mother?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)

  • When a congenital heart block is identified in a fetus, it is important to evaluate the mother for underlying conditions that may be associated with this condition. One of the primary conditions to consider is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues, including the heart. Maternal autoantibodies, specifically anti-Ro (SSA) and anti-La (SSB) antibodies, can cross the placenta and cause damage to the fetal heart, leading to a congenital heart block.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A (APLA syndrome): Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies, which can cause blood clotting and pregnancy complications. While it can be associated with fetal loss and placental insufficiency, it is not directly related to congenital heart block.

Option B (Congenital heart defects): Congenital heart defects refer to structural abnormalities in the heart that are present at birth. While congenital heart defects can occur in infants, they are not typically associated with the development of a congenital heart block.

Option D (Hemolytic anemia): Hemolytic anemia is a condition characterized by the destruction of red blood cells, leading to anemia. While it can have various causes, it is not directly related to the development of a congenital heart block.

questions.text: What is the preferred medication for managing bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Metronidazole- Metronidazole is an antibiotic that is effective against the bacteria commonly associated with bacterial vaginosis. It has been extensively studied and proven to be safe and effective in pregnancy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Fluconazole, is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections, such as yeast infections. It is not the recommended treatment for bacterial vaginosis.

Option C: Clindamycin, is another antibiotic that can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis. However, it is generally considered as an alternative to metronidazole and is reserved for cases where metronidazole cannot be used or if the infection does not respond to metronidazole.

Option D: Erythromycin is primarily used for the treatment of bacterial infections, but it is not the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: What is the purpose of using the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: PAP smear

  • A PAP smear is a screening test used to detect abnormal cells in the cervix.
  • The above intrument is Ayre spatula used in collecting cells from the cervix

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A (VIA): Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid (VIA) is a method used to visually examine the cervix after applying acetic acid to identify any visible abnormalities or lesions.

Option B (VILI): VILI is not a recognized medical term or abbreviation, and its specific meaning is unclear in the context provided.

Option D (Colposcopy): Colposcopy is a procedure that uses a specialized instrument called a colposcope to closely examine the cervix, vagina, and vulva for any abnormal areas or lesions.

questions.text: What is the stage classification for a case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm with lung metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C-III :

In stage III GTN, the cancer has spread to distant sites, including the lungs, but has not reached more distant organs or tissues. Lung metastasis indicates the involvement of distant sites beyond the primary tumor, which corresponds to stage III in the FIGO staging system for GTN.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A. I: Stage I GTN refers to localized disease confined to the uterus. Lung metastasis indicates spread to distant sites, indicating a more advanced stage than stage I.

Options B. II: Stage II GTN refers to disease that has spread beyond the uterus but remains within the genital structures. Lung metastasis indicates spread to distant sites beyond the genital structures, suggesting a higher stage than stage II.

Options D. IV: Stage IV GTN indicates widespread metastasis to distant organs, including the brain, liver, or other sites beyond the lungs. If the metastasis is limited to the lungs, it is not considered stage IV GTN.

questions.text: What is the most effective treatment choice for metropathia haemorrhagica?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A. Cyclical progesterone: This option is correct. Cyclical progesterone therapy involves the administration of progesterone during specific phases of the menstrual cycle. It helps regulate the endometrium (lining of the uterus) and stabilize the uterine lining, reducing the excessive and irregular bleeding associated with metropathia haemorrhagica.

 

;Incorrect Option :

Option B. Hysterectomy: It is usually reserved for cases where conservative measures have failed or when there are other underlying reasons to warrant the removal of the uterus.

Option C. Uterine artery embolization: This option is incorrect. Uterine artery embolization (UAE) is a procedure used to treat uterine fibroids, which are benign growths in the uterus. It is not the primary treatment for metropathia haemorrhagica.

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This option is incorrect. D&C provides temporary relief by removing excess endometrial tissue but does not address the underlying hormonal imbalance.

questions.text: What is the term used for egg cells that have been fertilized?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option: A Totipotent

  • Totipotent cells have the ability to differentiate into any cell type in an organism, including both embryonic and extraembryonic tissues. Fertilized egg cells, also known as zygotes, are the earliest stage of development in organisms. They are formed by the fusion of a sperm cell and an egg cell during fertilization. At this stage, the zygote has the potential to give rise to all the different cell types in the organism, including the cells that will form the placenta and other supporting structures.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Pluripotent: Pluripotent cells have the ability to differentiate into cells from all three germ layers of an organism (endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm). While pluripotent cells are present in later stages of embryonic development, the fertilized egg cell, or zygote, is considered totipotent because it has the potential to give rise to both embryonic and extraembryonic tissues.

Option C: Multipotent: Multipotent cells have the ability to differentiate into a limited number of cell types within a specific lineage or tissue. These cells are more restricted in their potential compared to totipotent or pluripotent cells. While multipotent cells are important in tissue repair and regeneration, the fertilized egg cell is not considered multipotent because it has the ability to develop into all cell types, not just a limited set of cell types.

Option D: None of the above: This is an incorrect choice because the fertilized egg cell, or zygote, is indeed totipotent, as explained above.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with short height, amenorrhea with widely spaced nipple visited to the OPD. What is the karyotype of this female?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: 45 XO

  • The karyotype refers to the specific chromosomal makeup of an individual. In this case, the 16-year-old girl presenting with short height, amenorrhea (absence of menstrual periods), and widely spaced nipples suggests a potential chromosomal abnormality associated with primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) or Turner syndrome.
  • Turner syndrome, also known as 45 XO syndrome, is a genetic condition that occurs in females who are missing all or part of one of their X chromosomes. The most common karyotype in Turner syndrome is 45 XO, indicating the presence of only one X chromosome instead of the normal two.
  • The characteristic features of Turner syndrome include short stature, delayed or absent puberty (amenorrhea), and specific physical characteristics such as widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and lymphedema (swelling due to lymphatic system abnormalities). Other associated findings may include infertility, cardiac abnormalities, renal anomalies, and learning difficulties.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: 46 XO: This karyotype does not exist. Humans typically have 46 chromosomes, and XO would imply the absence of a sex chromosome, which is not a viable combination.

Option C: 47 XXX: This karyotype indicates the presence of an additional X chromosome in females, known as Triple X syndrome. It is characterized by mild physical and developmental features, but it is not associated with the specific symptoms mentioned in the question.

Option D: 46 XY: This karyotype is typically associated with males. It represents the normal male chromosomal pattern. The symptoms described in the question, such as short height and amenorrhea, are not consistent with this karyotype.

questions.text: Which of the following Spermicidal cream  is used in contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: Nonoxynol -9

  • Nonoxynol-9 is a spermicidal agent commonly used in contraceptive methods. It is a surfactant that works by disrupting the cell membranes of sperm, thereby immobilizing and killing them. It is available in various forms such as creams, gels, foams, and suppositories. Nonoxynol-9 is typically applied directly to the cervix or inserted into the vagina before intercourse to provide contraception.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Gossypol: Gossypol is a natural compound derived from the cotton plant. While it has been studied for its potential contraceptive properties, it is not commonly used as a spermicidal cream. Gossypol's main use in contraception research has been focused on its effects on male fertility by inhibiting sperm production. However, its use as a contraceptive method is still under investigation and not widely available.

Option C: Centchroman: Centchroman, also known as oral contraceptive pill (OCP) or Saheli, is an oral contraceptive medication. It is a non-hormonal selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that inhibits ovulation, alters the endometrium, and suppresses sperm motility. It is taken orally as a tablet and not used as a spermicidal cream.

Option D: Clomiphene: Clomiphene is a medication commonly used in fertility treatment. It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts by stimulating the release of hormones necessary for ovulation. While it is involved in the process of enhancing fertility, it is not a spermicidal cream and is not used for contraception purposes.

questions.text: A 26 year old female presents with infertility and is diagnosed with a bilateral cornual block on hysterography. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Laparoscopy and hysteroscopy

  • When a lady presents with infertility and is diagnosed with bilateral cornual block on hysterography, the next step is typically a laparoscopy and hysteroscopy.
  • Laparoscopy is a surgical procedure that involves inserting a thin, lighted tube with a camera (laparoscope) through small incisions in the abdomen. It allows the doctor to examine the pelvic organs, including the fallopian tubes and ovaries, for any abnormalities such as blockages, adhesions, or endometriosis. In the case of bilateral cornual block, laparoscopy can help determine the cause of the blockage and assess the overall condition of the reproductive organs.
  • Hysteroscopy is a procedure that involves inserting a thin, lighted tube (hysteroscope) through the cervix into the uterus. It allows the doctor to directly visualize the inside of the uterus and detect any abnormalities, such as uterine polyps, fibroids, or adhesions, which may contribute to infertility.
  • By performing both laparoscopy and hysteroscopy, the doctor can assess the condition of both the fallopian tubes and the uterus simultaneously. This helps in identifying the specific cause of infertility and determining the most appropriate treatment options.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: IVF (In Vitro Fertilization): IVF is a treatment option for infertility, but it is not the next step in this case. Before proceeding with IVF, it is essential to identify the cause of infertility, and in this scenario, further diagnostic evaluation through laparoscopy and hysteroscopy is necessary.

Option B: Tuboplasty: Tuboplasty is a surgical procedure to repair or reconstruct the fallopian tubes. While it may be a treatment option for certain cases of tubal blockage or damage, it is not the next step in this scenario. Further evaluation through laparoscopy and hysteroscopy is required to assess the extent and location of the blockage before determining the appropriate treatment approach.

Option D: USG (Ultrasonography): Ultrasonography is a non-invasive imaging technique that can provide valuable information about the pelvic organs. While it can help detect some abnormalities, it is not sufficient to assess and diagnose the specific cause of bilateral cornual block. Laparoscopy and hysteroscopy are needed for a more detailed evaluation and direct visualization of the reproductive organs.

questions.text: Testosterone secreted by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Leydig cell

  • Leydig cells, also known as interstitial cells, are found in the testes and are responsible for the production and secretion of testosterone. These cells are located in the spaces between the seminiferous tubules within the testes.
  • Leydig cells are stimulated by luteinizing hormone (LH), which is released from the pituitary gland in response to signals from the hypothalamus. LH acts on the Leydig cells, triggering the production and release of testosterone into the bloodstream

Incorrect options:

Option B: Sertoli cell: Sertoli cells are found within the seminiferous tubules of the testes and play a vital role in supporting and nourishing the developing sperm cells. They provide nutrients, remove waste products, and create a suitable environment for sperm production. However, Sertoli cells do not produce testosterone.

Option C: Theca lutein: Theca lutein cells are specialized cells found in the ovaries, not the testes. They are involved in the production of hormones, particularly estrogen and progesterone, in the ovarian follicles during the menstrual cycle. Theca lutein cells do not secrete testosterone.

Option D: Granulosa cell: Granulosa cells are also found in the ovaries and are involved in the development and maturation of ovarian follicles. They play a role in the production of estrogen and progesterone. Granulosa cells do not produce testosterone.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl with acute bleeding per vaginal was presented to the clinic. What is immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Progesterone

  • Acute bleeding per vaginal in a 16-year-old girl can have various causes, including hormonal imbalances, anatomical abnormalities, or underlying medical conditions.
  • However, in adolescents, acute vaginal bleeding is often due to DUB, which is related to hormonal imbalances, particularly anovulation.
  • Progesterone is effective in the management of DUB as it helps stabilize the endometrium, reduce excessive bleeding, and promote regular menstrual cycles. Progesterone can be administered orally, as an injection, or in the form of hormonal contraceptives.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Uterine ablation: Uterine ablation is a surgical procedure that removes or destroys the endometrial lining and is typically reserved for older women with chronic abnormal uterine bleeding who have completed childbearing. It is not appropriate for a 16-year-old girl with acute vaginal bleeding.

Option B: Uterine artery block: Uterine artery embolization is used to treat uterine fibroids by blocking their blood supply. It is not indicated for the immediate management of acute vaginal bleeding in adolescents.

Option D: Hysteroscopy examination: Hysteroscopy is a diagnostic tool used to visualize the uterine cavity and may be useful for detecting structural abnormalities or retained products of conception. While it can be part of the diagnostic workup for chronic bleeding, it is not the immediate management for acute vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in the case of a hypertensive and diabetic 67-year-old woman presenting with profuse vaginal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option D: Endometrial biopsy

  • In a 67-year-old female presenting with heavy vaginal bleeding, the most appropriate next step in management is to perform an endometrial biopsy. This is because postmenopausal bleeding can be a sign of underlying pathology, including endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer. An endometrial biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure that involves obtaining a small sample of the endometrial tissue for histological examination.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Uterine ablation: Uterine ablation is a procedure used to treat abnormal uterine bleeding, but it is not appropriate as an initial management step for postmenopausal bleeding. It is important to first evaluate the cause of the bleeding through an endometrial biopsy.

Option B: Uterine artery block: Uterine artery block is not indicated as the initial management for postmenopausal bleeding. It is a procedure used to control bleeding in specific cases, such as in the setting of uterine fibroids or during certain gynecological surgeries.

Option C: Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy, the surgical removal of the uterus, is not the initial management for postmenopausal bleeding. It is a more invasive procedure that is considered when conservative measures fail or when there is a definitive diagnosis of endometrial cancer or other uterine pathology.

questions.text: A female presented to the clinic with complaints of amenorrhea and galactorrhea. What is he most likely diagnosis??
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Pituitary adenoma

  • When a woman presents with both amenorrhea (absence of menstrual periods) and galactorrhea (abnormal breast milk production), the most common cause is a pituitary adenoma, specifically a prolactin-secreting adenoma, also known as a prolactinoma.Prolactin is a hormone responsible for stimulating milk production in the breasts. In the presence of a prolactinoma, excess prolactin is secreted, leading to an inhibition of the reproductive hormones necessary for normal menstrual cycles and milk production.The combination of amenorrhea and galactorrhea in the absence of pregnancy or breastfeeding is highly suggestive of a prolactinoma.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Adrenal hyperplasia: Adrenal hyperplasia is a condition characterized by abnormal growth and functioning of the adrenal glands. It is not typically associated with amenorrhea and galactorrhea.

Option C: 70 alpha-hydroxylase deficiency: This is a specific type of adrenal hyperplasia that affects the production of cortisol and aldosterone. It is not directly associated with the symptoms of amenorrhea and galactorrhea.

Option D: None of the above: This option is incorrect because a pituitary adenoma, specifically a prolactinoma, is the most likely cause of amenorrhea and galactorrhea in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: What is the commonly preferred contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: OCP

  • Oral contraceptive pills, commonly known as birth control pills, are a widely used and highly effective contraceptive method. They contain synthetic hormones that prevent ovulation, thicken cervical mucus, and thin the uterine lining, making it difficult for sperm to reach the egg. OCPs offer both contraception and some non-contraceptive benefits, such as regulation of menstrual cycles and reduction of acne.

Incorrect Options:
