Option A: Barrier method: The barrier method, such as condoms or diaphragms, is a form of contraception that physically blocks sperm from reaching the egg. While it provides effective protection against pregnancy, it is important to note that it does not provide hormonal regulation .

Option C: Calendar method: The calendar method, also known as the rhythm method or fertility awareness-based method, involves tracking menstrual cycles to determine fertile and non-fertile days. While it is a natural and hormone-free method, it requires consistent and accurate monitoring of menstrual cycles, which can be challenging and less reliable, especially for individuals with irregular periods.

Option D: Progesterone-only pills: Progesterone-only pills, also called mini-pills, contain only progestin hormone. They are an alternative option for individuals who cannot or prefer not to take estrogen-containing contraceptives. Progesterone-only pills work by thickening cervical mucus, inhibiting ovulation, and thinning the uterine lining. They are effective in preventing pregnancy when taken consistently and correctly.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Investigation of choice for endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option D: Laparoscopy

Laparoscopy:

  • Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of endometriosis.
  • It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure where a thin, lighted instrument (laparoscope) is inserted through a small incision in the abdomen to visualize the pelvic organs.
  • During laparoscopy, the surgeon can directly visualize and biopsy endometrial lesions, providing a definitive diagnosis of endometriosis.
  • It allows for evaluation and staging of the disease, guiding appropriate treatment decisions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: CT (Computed Tomography)

  • CT scans are not the investigation of choice for diagnosing endometriosis.
  • CT scans provide detailed cross-sectional images of the body, but they are not specific or sensitive enough to identify endometriosis lesions accurately.

Option B: MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging)

  • While MRI can be helpful in some cases to evaluate certain features of endometriosis, it is not the primary investigation of choice.
  • MRI may be used to assess the extent of endometriosis and evaluate structures like the ovaries, uterus, and pelvic organs.
  • However, laparoscopy remains the gold standard for definitive diagnosis and visualization of endometriosis lesions.

Option C: USG (Ultrasound)

  • Transvaginal ultrasound (USG) is a non-invasive imaging modality that can provide some information about endometriosis, such as the presence of ovarian endometriomas (cysts).
  • However, it is not the primary investigation of choice for diagnosing endometriosis.
  • USG may show indirect signs of endometriosis, but it cannot definitively confirm the presence or extent of endometrial implants.

questions.text: What is the recommended dosage of mifepristone for emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: 25 mg

  • Mifepristone is a medication used for emergency contraception, also known as the "morning-after pill." It is most effective when taken as soon as possible after unprotected intercourse but no later than 72 hours (3 days) after.
  • The recommended dose of mifepristone for emergency contraception is 25 mg. This single oral dose is taken as a single tablet.

Incorrect options:

Options B, C, and D: These dosage are incorrect for emergency contraception.

questions.text: In a woman who had sexual intercourse 96 hours ago, which contraceptive method is the most appropriate choice?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device)

  • IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device): The IUCD, also known as a copper T, is a small device inserted into the uterus by a healthcare professional. It provides long-term contraception and can also be used as an emergency contraceptive method. It is effective when inserted within 120 hours (5 days) of unprotected intercourse, making it a suitable choice in this scenario.

Incorrect options:

Option A: OCP (Oral Contraceptive Pills): Oral contraceptive pills, commonly known as birth control pills, are taken daily to prevent pregnancy. However, they are not the best choice for emergency contraception after 96 hours (4 days) of unprotected intercourse. OCPs are most effective when taken within 72 hours (3 days) of intercourse.

Option C: Mifepristone: Mifepristone, also known as the "abortion pill," is primarily used for medical abortion. It is not typically used as a contraceptive method after unprotected intercourse.

Option D: Progesterone-only pills: Progesterone-only pills, also known as mini-pills, are a form of oral contraception that contains only progestin hormones. They are taken daily to prevent pregnancy. However, their effectiveness as emergency contraception after 96 hours is limited, and they are not considered the best option in this scenario.

questions.text: Beta hCG is secreted by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Syncytiotrophoblast:

  • Beta hCG is primarily secreted by the syncytiotrophoblast, a layer of cells in the placenta. It plays a crucial role in supporting early pregnancy and is used in pregnancy tests to detect the presence of hCG in the urine or blood.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Umbilical cord: The umbilical cord is a structure that connects the developing fetus to the placenta and provides a conduit for nutrients and oxygen. However, it is not a direct source of beta hCG.

Option C - Placenta: The placenta, including the syncytiotrophoblast layer, is the main source of beta hCG during pregnancy.

Option D - Yolk sac: The yolk sac is an early embryonic structure that plays a role in providing nutrients to the developing embryo. It is not a significant source of beta hCG.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate course of action for a 15-year-old girl who has not yet experienced her first menstrual period (primary amenorrhea), but displays the expected development of secondary sexual characteristics such as breast and pubic hair? Upon examination, no other abnormalities are found, and the patient denies any medication or illicit drug use. Furthermore, there is no significant family history that can explain the cause.
questions.solution:
Correct Options B - USG

(Ultrasonography): Ultrasonography is a non-invasive imaging technique that can help evaluate the pelvic organs. It can identify structural abnormalities such as absent or underdeveloped uterus and ovaries, which could be the cause of primary amenorrhea. This is often the first step in the evaluation process.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A. Reassure : While reassurance might be appropriate in some cases, further evaluation is necessary in the case of primary amenorrhea to rule out underlying conditions. It's essential to investigate the cause before providing reassurance.

Option C. HSG : Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a test used to examine the inside of the uterus and fallopian tubes. It is more relevant in cases of secondary infertility or recurrent pregnancy loss and is not the first-line investigation for primary amenorrhea.

Option D. Hormonal study: Hormonal studies, including measurement of hormones like FSH, LH, and estradiol, are important to assess the functioning of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. However, these are typically performed after imaging studies like ultrasonography to guide the diagnosis and management.

It's important for the patient to undergo ultrasonography to evaluate the pelvic anatomy, which can provide valuable information about the presence or absence of reproductive organs. Depending on the findings, further hormonal studies and consultations with specialists such as endocrinologists or gynecologists can be pursued for a comprehensive evaluation and appropriate management.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent diagnostic procedure for a 35-year-old female patient who is experiencing infertility and has a prior history of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), after initial assessments such as ultrasound (USG) revealing normal organs and hormone levels being within the normal range?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-Hysterosalpingography:

  • Hysterosalpingography is the next best investigation in this case.
  • It is used to evaluate the structure of the uterus and fallopian tubes and determine if there are any abnormalities, such as blockages or abnormalities of the fallopian tubes that may be causing infertility.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Repeat USG: Since the initial USG already showed normal findings, repeating it may not provide any new relevant information.

Option C. Endometrial biopsy: Endometrial biopsy is not the first-line investigation for infertility unless there are specific indications such as suspected endometrial pathology or irregularities in the menstrual cycle.

Option D. Urine culture and sensitivity: Urine culture and sensitivity are not directly related to the evaluation of infertility, especially in a case with a previous history of PID.

questions.text: Which of the following has the least risk of causing endometrial cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D-Multigravida:

  • Multigravida refers to a woman who has had multiple pregnancies. The risk of endometrial cancer is least in women who have had multiple pregnancies (multigravida).
  • Pregnancy and childbirth involve hormonal changes and shedding of the endometrial lining during menstruation, which can help reduce the risk of endometrial cancer.
  • Multiple pregnancies, especially full-term pregnancies, have been associated with a decreased risk of developing endometrial cancer.

Incorrect Options : 

Option A: A  positive family history: A positive family history of endometrial cancer increases the risk, as it may indicate a genetic predisposition or shared environmental factors.

Option B: Obesity: Obesity is a significant risk factor for endometrial cancer. Adipose tissue produces estrogen, and higher estrogen levels can promote the development of endometrial cancer.

Option C: Late menopause is a risk factor.

questions.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), what is the minimum sperm count required for a normal semen analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D-15 million/mL:

  • According to the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines, a minimum sperm count of 15 million sperm per milliliter (mL) of semen is considered within the normal range for semen analysis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: These are incorrect options

questions.text: Which hormone do the levels represented by the mark 'X' correspond to in this graph of a typical menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct option D:

  • Progesterone - Correct: Progesterone levels increase after ovulation and are responsible for preparing the uterus for potential implantation of a fertilized egg. The mark 'X' in the graph represents progesterone levels.

Incorrect options:

Option A. LH (Luteinizing Hormone) - Incorrect: LH levels typically spike around the middle of the menstrual cycle, leading to ovulation. In the given graph, the mark 'X' does not represent LH levels.

Option B. FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) - Incorrect: FSH levels are highest at the beginning of the menstrual cycle, promoting the development of ovarian follicles. The mark 'X' in the graph does not represent FSH levels.

Option C. Estrogen - Incorrect: Estrogen levels fluctuate throughout the menstrual cycle. They rise during the follicular phase and peak just before ovulation. The mark 'X' in the graph does not represent estrogen levels.

questions.text: What is the size of the uterus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B.

  • The correct option represents the size of the uterus as 3x2x1 inches. The other options provide different measurements that do not match the given size.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D: These are incorrect options

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be associated with a vaginal pH of 4?
questions.solution:
A vaginal pH of 4 is typically associated with

Option A. Atrophic vaginitis.

  • Atrophic vaginitis occurs due to thinning, drying, and inflammation of the vaginal walls, often caused by decreased estrogen levels, commonly seen in menopausal or postmenopausal women. The lack of estrogen leads to reduced glycogen content in vaginal epithelial cells, resulting in a lower pH (around 4) due to decreased lactic acid production.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Trichomonas vaginitis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It often presents with a vaginal pH higher than 5.

Option C. Candidal vaginitis (yeast infection) can cause an elevated pH, usually above 4.5.

Option D. Gardnerella vaginitis (bacterial vaginosis) is associated with a higher vaginal pH, typically above 4.5.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is LH: FSH ratio increased?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - PCOD:

  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by an increased ratio of luteinizing hormone (LH) to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). This hormonal imbalance disrupts normal ovulation and leads to the development of multiple ovarian cysts. 
  • High estrogen levels in PCOS lead to a very high LH levels and low FSH levels, leading to a LH:FSH ratio >2:1 or > 3:1(classical)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Premature menopause: Premature menopause is characterized by decreased ovarian function and lower levels of both LH and FSH.

Option B - Sheehan syndrome: Sheehan syndrome results from pituitary gland damage due to severe postpartum bleeding. It leads to decreased production of LH and FSH.

Option D - Turner's syndrome: Turner's syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence of one X chromosome. It results in decreased levels of both LH and FSH.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as a cause of primary amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Intrauterine adhesions:

  • Primary amenorrhea refers to the absence of menstruation in a woman by the age of 16 in the presence of normal secondary sexual characteristics. Sheehan's syndrome is a condition resulting from pituitary gland damage during childbirth, leading to secondary amenorrhea rather than primary amenorrhea.
  • Intrauterine adhesions is a cause of secondary amenorrhea which occurs due to Asherman syndrome or tuberculosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Swyer syndrome: This is one the most important cause of primary amenorrhea.

Option B - Kaftan's syndrome: There is no known condition or syndrome called Kaftan's syndrome related to amenorrhea.

Option D - Turner's syndrome: Turner's syndrome, caused by a missing or incomplete X chromosome, leads to primary amenorrhea due to ovarian dysgenesis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presenting with abdominal distension and pelvic discomfort is diagnosed with a malignancy, given her age group, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Epithelial ovarian cancer:

  • Epithelial ovarian cancer: Epithelial ovarian cancer is the most common ovarian malignancy in the elderly.
  • Given the age group of the patient, this is the most likely cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Granulosa cell tumor: Granulosa cell tumors are rare ovarian tumors that can occur in women of various age groups, including postmenopausal women. However, they are more commonly seen in younger women.

Option B - Dermoid cyst: While dermoid cysts can cause symptoms and complications, they are generally not classified as ovarian malignancies.

Option C - Mucinous cystadenoma: They are typically slow-growing and rarely transform into malignant tumors. Therefore, it is less likely to be associated with ovarian malignancy.

questions.text: Condyloma acuminate is caused by which of the following organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HPV:

  • Condyloma acuminatum, also known as genital warts, is primarily caused by certain strains of HPV. HPV is a sexually transmitted infection that can lead to the development of warts in the genital area.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): Genital warts are not caused by HSV. HSV is responsible for causing genital herpes, which manifests as painful sores or blisters.

Option B - HBV (Hepatitis B Virus): Condyloma acuminatum is not caused by HBV. HBV primarily affects the liver and can lead to hepatitis and other liver-related diseases.

Option D - HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus): Condyloma acuminatum is not caused by HIV. HIV is a virus that weakens the immune system and can lead to AIDS, but it does not directly cause genital warts.

questions.text: Which progestin is preferred for emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C-Levonorgestrel:

  • Levonorgestrel is the progesterone of choice for emergency contraception. It is a synthetic progestin that is commonly used in emergency contraceptive pills.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D: These are incorrect options

questions.text: What accurately describes the condition of a 22-year-old woman who complains of irregular menstrual cycles for a few months? Her cycles last 35-45 days, with a duration of 3-4 days and mild to moderate blood flow. There are no clots or dysmenorrhea.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Oligomenorrhea:

  • Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent or irregular menstrual cycles with intervals longer than 35 days. The described cycle length falls within this category.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Amenorrhea: Amenorrhea refers to the absence of menstruation for several months or more.

Option C - Polymenorrhea: Polymenorrhea refers to frequent menstrual cycles with intervals shorter than 21 days.

Option D - Menorrhagia: Menorrhagia refers to heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding, which is not described in the given scenario.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 45-year-old woman who has a lower abdominal mass and discomfort, with an examination revealing a uniformly enlarged uterus and free adnexa, and an MRI showing the presence of a myometrial cyst?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Adenomyosis:

  • Adenomyosis is a condition characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the muscular wall of the uterus (myometrium). It can lead to a uniformly enlarged uterus and is associated with symptoms such as lower abdominal discomfort, heavy menstrual bleeding, and menstrual cramps. The presence of a myometrial cyst, as seen on the MRI, is consistent with adenomyosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Endometriosis: Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, commonly involving the pelvic organs and peritoneal cavity.

Option C - Leiomyoma: Leiomyomastypically present as well-defined, solid masses within the uterus, rather than myometrial cysts as described in the case.

Option D - Endometrial hyperplasia:Endometrial hyperplasia can cause abnormal uterine bleeding but is not typically associated with a lower abdominal mass or the presence of myometrial cysts.

questions.text: In low ovarian reserve, what would be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) <1:

  • Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is a hormone produced by the ovarian follicles, and it is often used as a marker of ovarian reserve. Ovarian reserve refers to the number and quality of remaining eggs in the ovaries. A low ovarian reserve indicates a diminished number of eggs available for ovulation.
  • In cases of low ovarian reserve, the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is typically less than 1 ng/mL.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B) 1-4: This range is not indicative of low ovarian reserve. AMH levels within this range suggest a moderate to normal ovarian reserve.

Option C) >7: AMH levels greater than 7 ng/mL are not consistent with low ovarian reserve. Higher levels typically indicate a good ovarian reserve.

Option D) >10: AMH levels greater than 10 ng/mL are also not indicative of low ovarian reserve. Such levels are considered high and suggest a good ovarian reserve.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not considered a gestational trophoblastic neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Partial Mole: 

Partial Mole: partial mole is not a type of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm.

Malignant form of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm include:

  1. Invasive mole
  2. choriocarcinoma
  3. placental site trophoblastic tumor
  4. epithelioid trophoblastic tumor

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Choriocarcinoma: Choriocarcinoma is a type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm. It is an aggressive and malignant tumor that develops from trophoblastic cells.

Option C - Placental site trophoblastic tumor: Placental site trophoblastic tumor is another type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm. It arises from trophoblastic cells at the implantation site of the placenta.
Option D - Invasive mole : Invasive mole is also a type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm. It is characterized by the invasion of trophoblastic cells into the uterine wall.

questions.text: Which hormone acts on the endometrium after ovulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Progesterone:

  • After ovulation, the ruptured follicle transforms into a structure called the corpus luteum.
  • The corpus luteum produces progesterone, which is the hormone primarily responsible for preparing and maintaining the endometrium (the lining of the uterus) for potential implantation of a fertilized egg.
  • Progesterone helps to thicken the endometrium, increase its blood supply, and create a favorable environment for implantation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Luteinizing hormone (LH): LH plays a crucial role in triggering ovulation, which occurs around day 14 of the menstrual cycle. LH surge stimulates the release of the mature egg from the follicle.  

Option B - Follicular stimulating hormone (FSH): FSH stimulates the growth and development of ovarian follicles during the early phase of the menstrual cycle. It helps to promote the maturation of the egg within the follicle.

OptionD - Estrogen: Estrogen is mainly involved in the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle, preceding ovulation. It helps to rebuild and thicken the endometrium.

questions.text: What is an absolute contraindication to the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Thromboembolism:

  • Thromboembolism includes conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). OCPs containing estrogen have been associated with an increased risk of blood clot formation, and individuals with a history of thromboembolism are at higher risk for recurrence if they use OCPs.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Chronic renal disease: Chronic renal disease, or chronic kidney disease, is not an absolute contraindication to OCP use. However, caution may be required, and the use of OCPs should be done, considering factors like the severity of renal disease, the presence of complications, and individual patient characteristics.

Options C - History of amenorrhea: Amenorrhea refers to the absence of menstrual periods. While it may indicate an underlying hormonal imbalance or reproductive issue, it is not a contraindication to OCP use. In fact, OCPs are sometimes prescribed to regulate menstrual cycles and manage certain hormonal conditions causing amenorrhea.

Options D - Diabetes mellitus: Diabetes mellitus is not an absolute contraindication to OCP use. However, it is important to consider the individual's overall health status, any associated complications, and the potential impact of OCPs on blood sugar control. Close monitoring and adjustment of diabetes management may be necessary in individuals with diabetes who use OCPs.

questions.text: What is the specific chromosome count observed in a partial hydatidiform mole?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 69 XXY:

  • A partial hydatidiform mole, also known as a partial molar pregnancy, is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease characterized by abnormal development of the placenta.
  • The chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole is typically 69, with two sets of paternal chromosomes (from the father) and one set of maternal chromosomes (from the mother).
  • Karyotype can be 69XXX, 69XXY, 69XYY, but never 69YYY

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 46 XX: A normal karyotype for a female individual is 46 XX, which represents two sets of chromosomes (one set from each parent) and indicates a typical female chromosomal configuration.  

Option B - 45 XY: A 45 XY karyotype is indicative of Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the complete or partial absence of one X chromosome in individuals assigned male at birth.

OptionC - 69 XY: A 69 XY karyotype represents a triploid condition with two sets of paternal chromosomes and one set of maternal chromosomes. However, this chromosomal configuration is not specific to a partial hydatidiform mole.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a 55-year-old woman who is experiencing third-degree uterine prolapse?

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vaginal Hysterectomy with Pelvic Floor Repair:

  • A third-degree uterine prolapse occurs when the uterus has descended to or beyond the vaginal opening. In a 55-year-old postmenopausal woman who is experiencing this degree of prolapse, vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the most appropriate treatment.

  • Vaginal hysterectomy is the removal of the uterus through the vaginal route, which is commonly recommended in cases of uterine prolapse, especially when future childbearing is not a concern (e.g., in postmenopausal women).
  • Pelvic floor repair (also called pelvic reconstructive surgery) involves repairing the weakened pelvic tissues that caused the prolapse. This may include procedures like anterior and posterior colporrhaphy (repair of the vaginal walls) and perineorrhaphy (repair of the perineum) to restore pelvic support.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fothergill Repair:

  • This procedure is used for uterine prolapse but is typically performed in younger women who wish to preserve their uterus and maintain fertility.
  • The cervix is amputated, and the uterosacral ligaments are attached to the cervical stump to provide support.
  • In a 55-year-old woman, especially postmenopausal, fertility is not a concern, and uterine preservation is unnecessary. Therefore, vaginal hysterectomy is the more appropriate treatment.

Option B - Sling Operation:

  • A sling operation is also primarily used for stress urinary incontinence and involves the placement of a supportive sling around the urethra to improve urinary control. It is not the best management option for uterine prolapse alone.

Option D - Shirodkar Procedure:

  • The Shirodkar procedure is a surgical technique used for cervical incompetence and involves the placement of a permanent suture around the cervix to strengthen it and prevent premature opening. It is not indicated for uterine prolapse management.

questions.text: In emergency contraception, what is the recommended dosage of Ulipristal?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 30 mg:

  • Ulipristal acetate is a medication used for emergency contraception. The recommended dose for emergency contraception is a single oral dose of 30 mg. This dose has been shown to be effective in inhibiting or delaying ovulation when taken within 72 hrs (upto 120 hrs)after unprotected intercourse.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D: These options are incorrect

questions.text: What should be the subsequent approach to treat a pregnant woman, aged 22, who continues to have a fever despite being prescribed antibiotics, and is later diagnosed with septic pelvic thrombophlebitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Antibiotics + Heparin:

  • The standard management for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis involves a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat the underlying infection and anticoagulation therapy (usually with heparin) to prevent the extension of thrombosis and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stop antibiotics and start heparin - This option is not appropriate because septic pelvic thrombophlebitis is a severe infection that requires both antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy. Stopping antibiotics would not address the underlying infection.

Option C - Surgical embolectomy - Surgical embolectomy is not the first-line treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. It may be considered in cases of severe sepsis or if there is no response to medical therapy, but it is not typically the initial course of treatment.

Option D - Hysterectomy - Hysterectomy is not the primary treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. It may be considered in cases of severe infection or if there are specific indications for hysterectomy, such as uncontrolled bleeding or uterine pathology, but it is not the first-line treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis.

questions.text: For a woman experiencing itching due to atrophic vaginitis, which treatment option is preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Topical estrogen:

  • Atrophic vaginitis is a condition characterized by inflammation and thinning of the vaginal tissues due to decreased estrogen levels, commonly seen in postmenopausal women. The mainstay of treatment for atrophic vaginitis is topical estrogen therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Steroids are not the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis. While steroids may have anti-inflammatory properties and can provide temporary relief from itching, they do not address the underlying cause of atrophic vaginitis.

Option C - Antihistamines are primarily used to relieve allergic symptoms and are not the appropriate treatment for atrophic vaginitis. While antihistamines may help alleviate itching, they do not address the underlying hormonal changes.

Option D - "None of the above" is incorrect because topical estrogen therapy, represented by option B, is indeed the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 55-year-old woman who presents with abnormal uterine bleeding and undergoes a hysterectomy, resulting in the retrieval of the following specimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Leiomyoma:

  • The provided image shows a characteristic leiomyoma,
  • leiomyomas, or uterine fibroids, are benign tumors that arise from the smooth muscle cells of the uterus.
  • They can cause abnormal uterine bleeding and are typically well-circumscribed with a whorled appearance on histological examination. I

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Endometrial carcinoma: Endometrial carcinoma refers to cancerous growth in the lining of the uterus (endometrium). It can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in postmenopausal women.

Option C - Endometrial polyp: Endometrial polyps are benign growths that develop within the endometrial lining of the uterus. They can cause abnormal uterine bleeding and are typically detected through hysteroscopy or histological examination.

Option D - Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis is a condition characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the muscular wall of the uterus. It can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, and uterine enlargement.

questions.text: What determines the destiny of the Mullerian duct?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Y chromosome:

  • The fate of the Müllerian duct is determined by the presence of the Y chromosome in individuals with male biological sex.
  • The Müllerian ducts, which are paired embryonic structures, develop into the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper part of the vagina in the absence of the Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS) produced by the Sertoli cells of the developing testes.
  • The Y chromosome contains the SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene, which initiates the development of testes and the subsequent production of MIS, leading to the regression of the Müllerian ducts.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - X chromosome: This option is incorrect. The presence of the X chromosome alone does not determine the fate of the Müllerian duct. The X chromosome carries genetic information related to various traits and functions, but it does not directly influence the development of the Müllerian duct.

Option C - 1st chromosome: This option is incorrect. Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes, numbered from 1 to 22, plus the sex chromosomes (X and Y). The fate of the Müllerian duct is not determined by a specific "1st chromosome."

Option D - 2nd chromosome: This option is incorrect. The sex chromosomes in humans are labeled as X and Y, and the Müllerian duct development is specifically influenced by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome.

questions.text: After the insertion of a pessary, what is the initial action to assess its proper retention?

choices.text: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place:

  • This is the appropriate first step to check if the pessary is adequately retained.
  • The Valsalva maneuver involves asking the patient to bear down or strain as if having a bowel movement while holding their breath.
  • This maneuver increases intra-abdominal pressure, and if the pessary is properly fitted and retained, it should remain in place during the maneuver.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place- Voiding (urinating) does not specifically test the retention of the pessary.

Option B - Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained- The presence or absence of discomfort alone is not a reliable indicator of whether the pessary is adequately retained.

Option D - Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary - Admitting two fingers between the ring and the pessary suggests that the pessary is not adequately fitted or retained.

questions.text:
What is the likely diagnosis for a 16-year-old girl presenting with primary amenorrhea and the following characteristics?


	Normal stature
	Thelarche – absent
	FSH, LH – high
	Karyotype – 46 XX
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Gonadal dysgenesis:

  • Gonadal dysgenesis - This option is the most probable diagnosis for the given features.
  • Gonadal dysgenesis refers to the incomplete development or absence of the gonads (ovaries or testes).
  • It can present with primary amenorrhea, but the presence of high FSH and LH levels suggests ovarian dysfunction.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Testicular feminizing syndrome (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome) - It occurs in karyotype XY.

Option C - Kallmann syndrome - Kallmann syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by delayed or absent puberty due to a deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion. It has low LH and FSH

Option D - Turner syndrome - Turner syndrome is a genetic condition that occurs in females with a missing or incomplete X chromosome (45 XO karyotype).

questions.text: Fimbriectomy is also known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Kroener’s procedure:

  • The technique of fimbriectomy as described by Kroener employs the ligation of the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures and then division and removal of the infundibulum of the tube.
  • Ligation and hemostasis are accomplished simultaneously.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pomeroy technique - This is most commonly done, wherein a single ligature is used, and ends are cut. However, the tube cut end are together, which can lead to fistula formation leading to failure

Option B - Uchida’s procedure - Sub Serosal Dissection of Tube (UCHIDA'S Procedure): Serosa is lifted by needle & saline is injected, then serosa is incised, and tube is resected. The serosa is sutured again. The advantage is that fibrosis & adhesions are very less, as cut ends are within the serosa

Option D - Irwing’s procedure -One end of tube is buried into uterine musculature and the other end of tube is buried into mesosalpinx

questions.text: What should be the next step in managing a 45-year-old woman who presents with post-coital bleeding and has a positive pap smear result?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Colposcopy directed biopsy:

  • In cases of post-coital bleeding and a positive pap smear, colposcopy directed biopsy is an appropriate next step to further evaluate the cervix and obtain tissue samples for pathological examination.
  • Colposcopy allows for a detailed visualization of any abnormal areas and helps guide targeted biopsies of suspicious lesions.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cone biopsy- Cone biopsy may be considered if colposcopy reveals significant abnormalities or if there is a need for more extensive tissue sampling. However, it is not the initial step in the management of post-coital bleeding and a positive pap smear.

Option C - Repeat pap smear- A repeat pap smear may be indicated in certain circumstances, such as if the initial pap smear was inadequate or if there are concerns about sample quality.

Option D - Hysterectomy- Hysterectomy, the surgical removal of the uterus, is not the initial management for post-coital bleeding and a positive pap smear.

questions.text: Which of the options below does not describe the mechanism of action of progesterone-only pills?

choices.text: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Kills the sperms in the cervical canal:

  • Progesterone-only pills do not have a direct spermicidal effect.
  • Their main mechanism of action is related to cervical mucus changes and inhibiting sperm penetration.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Thicken the cervical mucus- Progesterone-only pills work by thickening the cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to pass through the cervix and reach the uterus. This mechanism helps to prevent fertilization.

Option B - Prevents ovulation- progesterone-only pills primarily work by inhibiting ovulation.

Option D - Inhibits penetration of sperm- Progesterone-only pills can inhibit the penetration of sperm into the upper reproductive tract by altering the cervical mucus consistency. The thickened cervical mucus serves as a physical barrier to prevent sperm from reaching the fallopian tubes and fertilizing an egg.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions may result from chronic pelvic inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pyometra:

  • Long-standing pelvic inflammation, particularly involving the uterus and fallopian tubes, can lead to the development of pyometra.
  • Pyometra is a condition characterized by the accumulation of pus within the uterine cavity. It is usually associated with bacterial infection and can occur as a result of untreated or chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Uterine polyposis- Uterine polyposis refers to the presence of multiple polyps in the uterine cavity. While chronic inflammation can contribute to the development of uterine polyps, it is not specifically linked to long-standing pelvic inflammation as a direct consequence.

Option C - Pseudocyesis- Pseudocyesis, also known as false pregnancy or phantom pregnancy, is a condition in which a person experiences symptoms of pregnancy, such as missed periods, abdominal enlargement, and even perceived fetal movements, despite not being pregnant.

Option D - Endometrial hyperplasia- Endometrial hyperplasia refers to the excessive proliferation of the endometrium, the inner lining of the uterus. While chronic inflammation may contribute to endometrial hyperplasia in some cases, it is not the primary outcome of long-standing pelvic inflammation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient visits the outpatient department (OPD) with a complaint of a mass descending through the vaginal opening. Upon examination, it is determined to be a second-degree uterovaginal prolapse. The patient does not have any chronic illnesses and does not smoke or consume alcohol. She has previously undergone two vaginal deliveries, one 8 years ago and the other 10 years ago with Episiotomy. The doctor proceeds to gather a detailed obstetric history pertaining to these two deliveries. Which of the following factors in the patient's history is unlikely to have contributed to her current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Episiotomy

  • The correct option that would not lead to the present condition (uterovaginal prolapse) is Episiotomy.
  • However, an episiotomy is not directly associated with uterovaginal prolapse. It is more commonly linked to issues like perineal pain, wound infection, and discomfort during sexual intercourse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Precipitate labor: Precipitate labor refers to an extremely fast labor and delivery process, often lasting less than 3 hours from the onset of contractions to the birth of the baby. This rapid delivery can put significant stress on the pelvic floor muscles and tissues, potentially contributing to uterovaginal prolapse.

Option B: Prolonged second stage: The second stage of labor is the phase from full cervical dilation to the birth of the baby. If this stage is prolonged, it means the woman has been pushing for an extended period. Prolonged pushing can strain the pelvic floor and supporting structures, increasing the risk of uterovaginal prolapse.

Option C: Premature bearing down: Premature bearing down refers to the urge to push before the cervix is fully dilated. Pushing too early can lead to excessive pressure on the pelvic structures and may contribute to the development of uterovaginal prolapse.

questions.text: What is the conservative approach used to treat pelvic organ prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct option C-What is the conservative approach used to treat pelvic organ prolapse?:

  • Conservative management options for pelvic organ prolapse include the use of a pessary . A pessary is a removable device that is inserted into the vagina to provide support to the prolapsed organs and alleviate symptoms. It is a non-surgical approach that can be effective in managing mild to moderate cases of pelvic organ prolapse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Perineorrhaphy: Perineorrhaphy is a surgical procedure that involves repairing and strengthening the perineal tissues but is not a conservative treatment for pelvic organ prolapse.

Option B:Shirodkar Procedure: The Shirodkar procedure is a surgical technique used for cervical cerclage during pregnancy and is not a conservative treatment for pelvic organ prolapse.

Option D: Le Fort Repair: Le Fort repair refers to surgical techniques used for the treatment of urinary incontinence and is not a conservative treatment for pelvic organ prolapse.

questions.text: 28 year old lady (G2 P1) who does not want to conceive after abortion, which is the preferred mode of contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-IUD:

  • Intrauterine devices (IUDs) are considered one of the most effective forms of reversible contraception. They are a preferred mode of contraception for women who do not wish to conceive after an abortion. IUDs are long-acting, reversible contraceptives that are inserted into the uterus by a healthcare provider. They provide reliable contraception for an extended period, and their effectiveness is not dependent on user compliance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: OCP (Oral contraceptive pills): Although oral contraceptive pills are a commonly used form of contraception, they require regular daily intake and may not be the preferred choice for individuals who do not wish to conceive after an abortion.

Option C: Barrier methods: Barrier methods such as condoms or diaphragms provide contraception by physically blocking the sperm from reaching the egg. While they offer some level of protection, they are less effective than long-acting reversible methods like IUDs.

Option D: Implant: Implants are small, flexible rods inserted under the skin that release hormones to prevent pregnancy. While they are highly effective, they may not be the preferred choice for individuals who do not wish to conceive after an abortion.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female patient visits the doctor with concerns about her irregular menstrual periods and experiencing bleeding after sexual intercourse for the past 2 months. The patient comes from a low socio-economic background and has 4 children. She uses an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) for birth control. Additionally, the patient has a long history of smoking and has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 5 years. The patient's vital signs are stable, and the physical examination does not reveal any significant findings. Further investigations indicate a positive test for type 16 human papillomavirus (HPV) and a biopsy confirms the presence of cervical cancer in its early stage. Which of the following factors from her medical history does not contribute to her current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-Hypertension and IUCD use:

  • The factors in this patient's history that are associated with an increased risk of developing cervical cancer are chronic smoking (smoking is a well-established risk factor for cervical cancer) and the presence of high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) type 16 infection.
  • However, hypertension and the use of an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) do not predispose her to cervical cancer (Ans. B). Hypertension and IUCD use are not known risk factors for the development of cervical cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: HPV 16, smoking: Both high-risk HPV 16 infection and smoking are well-established risk factors for cervical cancer.

Option C: Multiparity and low socio-economic status: Multiparity (having multiple pregnancies) and low socio-economic status are associated with a higher risk of developing cervical cancer.

Option D: Multiparity and smoking: Multiparity and smoking are both known risk factors for cervical cancer.

questions.text: What is the chromosomal pattern in complete mole?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C-46 XX both paternal origin:

  • A complete mole, also known as a complete hydatidiform mole, is an abnormal pregnancy characterized by the absence of a fetus and the presence of abnormal trophoblastic tissue. In a complete mole, the genetic material is entirely paternal, meaning both sets of chromosomes (XX or XY) are derived from the father. The maternal chromosomes are absent.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 46 XY both maternal origin: This option is incorrect because a complete mole is characterized by a complete absence of maternal genetic material.

Option B: 46 XX both maternal origin: This option is incorrect because a complete mole is characterized by a complete absence of maternal genetic material.

Option D: 46 YY both paternal origin: This option is incorrect because the presence of YY chromosomes is not possible in humans.

questions.text: In a patient who is a 32-year-old female, experiencing her first pregnancy at full term, and has a previously diagnosed fibroid uterus, an elective cesarean section is being planned due to the baby being in a breech presentation. The patient expresses her desire to have the fibroid removed during the surgery. However, she has been informed about the potential drawbacks of undergoing myomectomy. Which of the following conditions is a reason to consider removing the fibroid in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A-Pedunculated subserosal:

  • In this scenario, the patient has a known history of the fibroid uterus and desires its removal during the cesarean section. However, in certain cases, myomectomy may not be recommended. One such indication for removal is a pedunculated subserosal fibroid. Pedunculated fibroids have a stalk-like structure that allows them to protrude from the uterus.
  • A pedunculated subserosal fibroid located on the outer surface of the uterus is more accessible for removal during the cesarean section, and its removal can prevent potential complications such as torsion or obstruction during future pregnancies.

Incorrect options:

Option B: In the broad ligament: Fibroids in this location can be challenging to access and remove during surgery, and their removal may increase the risk of bleeding and damage to nearby structures.

Option C: Posterior in location: The location of the fibroid, whether anterior (front) or posterior (back) in the uterus, does not necessarily determine the need for removal during a cesarean section.

Option D: Small in size: Small fibroids that are not causing symptoms or complications do not typically require removal during a cesarean section.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent infections is frequently associated with infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Chlamydia:

  • Chlamydia infection is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. If left untreated, chlamydia can lead to various complications, including pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which can cause scarring and damage to the reproductive organs. This scarring can lead to infertility in both men and women.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Trichomoniasis: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. While it can cause symptoms such as vaginal discharge and discomfort, it is not commonly associated with infertility.

Option C: Candidiasis: Candidiasis, commonly known as a yeast infection, is caused by the overgrowth of the fungus Candida. It typically affects the vagina but does not usually lead to infertility.

Option D: Bacterial vaginosis: Bacterial vaginosis is an imbalance of the normal vaginal flora, characterized by an overgrowth of certain bacteria. While it can cause symptoms and discomfort, it is not commonly associated with infertility.

questions.text: What initial tests should be recommended to this couple, a 29-year-old woman who has been unable to conceive for 3 years, and her husband, who have been married for 4 years, live together, and are sexually active without using contraception? The woman's menstrual cycle occurs at regular 28-day intervals, and her husband is a professional cyclist.

choices.text: Semen analysis, Tubal patency test, Ovulation test
Testicular biopsy, USG, Sperm penetration test

questions.solution:
Correct option: B

  • In the evaluation of infertility, initial tests should focus on assessing factors that could contribute to the difficulty in conceiving. In this case, the couple has been trying to conceive for 3 years without success. The initial tests that should be advised are:
  1. Semen analysis: It assesses factors such as sperm count, motility, and morphology, which are important for successful fertilization.
  2. Tubal patency test: This test assesses the patency (openness) of the woman's fallopian tubes. Ovulation test: This test helps determine if the woman is ovulating regularly.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Semen analysis, CXR, Mantoux test (Ans. A): A chest X-ray (CXR) and Mantoux test are not relevant in the initial evaluation of infertility.

Option C: Ovulation, tubal patency, Mantoux test (Ans. C): The Mantoux test is used for diagnosing tuberculosis and is not necessary in the initial evaluation of infertility.

Option D: Testicular biopsy, USG, Sperm penetration test (Ans. D): Testicular biopsy and sperm penetration test are more specialized tests that are typically reserved for specific situations or after initial evaluations have been conducted.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about endometriosis?

choices.text: Presence of endometrial gland in deep myometrium
Presence of endometrium at ectopic locations

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Endometriosis is a condition characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus. The endometrial tissue can implant and grow in various ectopic locations, such as the ovaries, fallopian tubes, pelvic peritoneum, and other sites within the pelvis and abdomen. This ectopic endometrial tissue responds to hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle, leading to inflammation, scarring, and pain.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Presence of endometrial gland in deep myometrium: This statement is not true. In endometriosis, the endometrial tissue is primarily found outside the uterus, in areas such as the pelvic cavity or other ectopic sites, rather than within the deep myometrium (muscular layer of the uterus).

Option C: Treated preferably with hysterectomy: Hysterectomy (removal of the uterus) is not the first-line treatment for endometriosis. The initial approach involves medical management, including pain management and hormonal therapies. Hysterectomy may be considered in severe cases or when other treatments have failed, but it is not the preferred treatment option.

Option D: Seen in multiparous women: Endometriosis can occur in women regardless of their parity (number of pregnancies). It is not limited to multiparous women (women who have had multiple pregnancies).

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of infertility in a 29-year-old female who has a history of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • The most probable cause of infertility in a 29-year-old female with a history of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia is Endometriosis.

 

Incorrect Options:
 

Option A. Adenomyomatosis: The misplaced tissue in adenomyosis does not usually interfere significantly with fertility.

Option C. Myomas (Uterine Fibroids): The impact on fertility depends on the size, location, and number of fibroids. Small fibroids that do not distort the uterine cavity are unlikely to cause infertility issues.

Option D. Cervicitis: In most cases, cervicitis can be treated effectively with antibiotics and does not necessarily lead to infertility.

questions.text: What is the most probable reason for a 30-year-old woman visiting a clinician due to abundant facial hair and hair growth on her upper back, arms, and thighs?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-PCOS:

  • Excessive growth of facial hair in women, known as hirsutism, is commonly associated with hormonal imbalances. One of the most likely causes in this scenario is PCOS.
  • Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome is a common endocrine disorder characterized by hormonal imbalances, including elevated levels of androgens (male hormones). These elevated androgen levels can lead to hirsutism and other symptoms such as irregular periods, acne, and ovarian cysts.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A: Drug-induced: Certain medications can cause hirsutism as a side effect, but in the absence of medication history, PCOS is a more likely cause.

Option C: Endometriosis: Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus. While it can cause pelvic pain and other symptoms, it is not typically associated with hirsutism.

Option D: Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis is a condition where the endometrial tissue grows into the muscular wall of the uterus. It primarily causes heavy or painful periods but is not associated with excessive facial hair growth.

questions.text: What is the correct statement about the condition of a 52-year-old woman who visits a physician complaining of experiencing warm spells followed by excessive sweating, and has not had menstrual periods for the past 3 years?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D

  • The symptoms described by the patient, including hot flashes (warm spells) and profuse sweating, along with the cessation of periods for 3 years, are indicative of menopause. During menopause, there is a decline in ovarian function and hormone production.
  • The correct hormonal changes associated with menopause are increased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels and decreased estrogen levels. As the ovaries produce less estrogen, the negative feedback on the anterior pituitary is reduced, leading to increased FSH secretion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: These are incorrect options

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: Targeted biopsy

In a 40-year-old woman presenting with postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in the cervix, the next step in management would be a targeted biopsy. This procedure involves obtaining a tissue sample from the abnormal area for further evaluation and diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Conisation (cone biopsy) While it may be performed in cases of abnormal findings on a Pap smear or colposcopy, it is not the initial step in this scenario.

Option B: Cryotherapy Cryotherapy involves using extreme cold to destroy abnormal tissue. While it can be used as a treatment option for certain cervical abnormalities, it is not the first step in evaluation. Option D: Pap smear A Pap smear is a screening test used to detect abnormal changes in cervical cells. However, in the case of a visible mass and postcoital bleeding, a targeted biopsy is more appropriate as it provides a specific tissue sample for evaluation.

questions.text: Which of the following is Hormone replacement therapy not used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is B-CAD Prophylaxis:

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) is not indicated for CAD (Coronary Artery Disease) prophylaxis. HRT refers to the use of hormones, typically estrogen and progesterone, to alleviate symptoms and manage certain conditions related to hormonal imbalances.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Hot flashes - Hormone Replacement Therapy is commonly used to alleviate hot flashes, which are a common symptom of menopause.

Option C: Osteoporosis - Hormone Replacement Therapy can be used to manage osteoporosis, a condition characterized by reduced bone density and increased risk of fractures.

Option D: Premature menopause - Hormone Replacement Therapy may be considered in cases of premature menopause, which occurs before the age of 40, to provide hormonal support and manage associated symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

questions.solution:
Correct Options is A: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached to the cell surface: It is most likely indicative of a condition called bacterial vaginosis (BV).

One of the hallmark microscopic findings in BV is the presence of clue cells, which are epithelial cells coated with bacteria adhering to their surface. The bacteria seen in BV are typically Gardnerella vaginalis and other anaerobic bacteria.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B: Bacteria engulfed by macrophages: This finding suggests the presence of macrophages, which are immune cells responsible for engulfing and destroying bacteria.

Option C: Neutrophil engulfed bacteria: Neutrophils are another type of immune cell that is commonly involved in fighting bacterial infections.

Option D: Bacteria arranged in clusters: The presence of bacteria arranged in clusters is not characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. This finding could be more suggestive of other bacterial infections, such as group B streptococcal infection or staphylococcal infection, where bacteria tend to form clusters.

questions.text: Which cervical cancer vaccination is preferred for a 16-year-old unmarried female visiting the gynecology OPD?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Gardasil: Gardasil is a vaccine that provides protection against certain strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV), which is a known cause of cervical cancer. It is recommended for both males and females to prevent HPV infection and its associated complications, including cervical cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Biovac, is not a specific vaccine for cervical cancer or HPV. It is important to choose a vaccine specifically designed to target the strains of HPV that are associated with cervical cancer.

Option C: Rabivac, is a vaccine used for the prevention of rabies, not for cervical cancer.

Option D: Tvac, is not a recognized vaccine for cervical cancer or HPV. It is essential to select a vaccine that has been extensively studied and approved for the prevention of cervical cancer.

questions.text: Non – pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B-Male infertility:

  • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are commonly used in various medical conditions. These medications work by suppressing the release of gonadotropins, which are hormones that stimulate the production of sex hormones in the body. In certain conditions, a non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used, meaning a continuous or sustained dose is administered.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Endometriosis: The non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist helps suppress the production of estrogen and provides relief from pain and other symptoms associated with endometriosis.

Option C. Precocious puberty: The continuous or non-pulsatile administration of GnRH agonist helps suppress the premature release of sex hormones and slows down the progression of puberty.

Option D. Carcinoma prostate: The non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used to maintain a continuous suppression of testosterone levels and inhibit the growth of prostate cancer.

questions.text:
Assertion: Hot flushes are common after menopause

Reason: Hot flushes are because of low estrogen or its fluctuatio

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Assertion is false, but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

  • Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is correct. Hot flushes are indeed common after menopause. During menopause, the levels of estrogen fluctuate and eventually decrease, leading to hormonal imbalances. The decrease in estrogen is considered the primary cause of hot flushes. Therefore, the reason provided accurately explains the assertion.

Incorrect option:

Option B, C, and D: These options are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided in a 23 years old second gravida with DVT who is already on warfarin ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A. LNG IUCD is a form of intrauterine contraceptive device that releases the hormone levonorgestrel. This hormone can potentially increase the risk of blood clots, and therefore, it is generally not recommended for individuals with a history of DVT or those who are already on anticoagulant therapy like warfarin.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Progesterone-only pills: Progesterone-only pills, also known as mini-pills, contain only progestin and not estrogen. They are generally considered safe for individuals with a history of DVT.

Option C. Implanon: Implanon is a contraceptive implant that releases etonogestrel, a form of progestin. Similar to progesterone-only pills, etonogestrel-containing implants are generally considered safe for individuals with a history of DVT.

Option D. Depo-Provera: Depo-Provera is a progestin-only injectable contraceptive. Similar to progesterone-only pills and etonogestrel implants, it is generally considered safe for individuals with a history of DVT.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who experiences excessive menstrual bleeding and exhibits the following finding during hysteroscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D-Submucosal fibroid:

  • Submucosal fibroid: This is the correct option for the given finding. Submucosal fibroids are benign growths that develop within the uterine wall and protrude into the uterine cavity. They can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, as seen in the patient described in the question.
  • They are classified as Type 0 under FIGO classification.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Asherman syndrome: Asherman syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions or scar tissue that can develop following uterine surgery or infection.

Option B. Cervical carcinoma: Cervical carcinoma refers to cancerous growth in the cervix. Hysteroscopy primarily evaluates the uterine cavity, not the cervix.

Option C. Endometrial carcinoma: Endometrial carcinoma is cancer that develops in the lining of the uterus (endometrium).

questions.text: What is the appropriate approach to managing a 76-year-old woman who has a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora measuring 2 cm x 3 cm for the past 6 months, with no palpable lymph nodes, and biopsy indicating squamous cell carcinoma?

choices.text: Total vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection
Radical local excision with U/L LAD

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Radical local excision with U/L LAD:

  • In this case, the patient presents with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora that has been persistent for 6 months. The appropriate management for this case would be a Radical local excision with U/L LAD

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Total vulvectomy with unilateral lymph node dissection: Total vulvectomy involves the complete removal of the vulva, which may not be necessary in this case, as the tumor is limited to the labia majora. Additionally, unilateral lymph node dissection would not be sufficient because the tumor could potentially spread to the contralateral side.

Option C - Simple vulvectomy: Simple vulvectomy involves the removal of the tumor along with a margin of healthy tissue, without lymph node dissection. However, in cases where there is a risk of lymph node involvement, as indicated by the size and characteristics of the tumor, lymph node dissection is necessary for accurate staging and to guide further treatment.

Option D - Chemoradiation with resection: Chemoradiation with resection may be considered as an alternative treatment approach in some cases, but it is not the primary management option for squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. Surgery, such as vulvectomy, is typically the initial treatment of choice, especially if the tumor is localized and resectable.

questions.text: What is the crucial indicator of male fertility in a semen analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Morphology:

  • Morphology refers to the shape and structure of sperm cells. It is assessed by examining sperm under a microscope and determining the percentage of sperm cells that have normal morphology. Normal sperm morphology is crucial for successful fertilization, as it affects the sperm's ability to penetrate and fertilize the egg.

Incorrect Options:

OptionB. Concentration: Concentration refers to the number of sperm cells present in a given volume of semen. While sperm concentration is an important parameter in semen analysis, it alone does not provide a comprehensive assessment of male fertility.

Option C. Motility: Motility refers to the sperm's ability to move and swim forward. It is an important parameter in semen analysis as it indicates the sperm's ability to reach and penetrate the egg for fertilization.

Option D. Sperm Count: Sperm count refers to the total number of sperm cells in the ejaculate. The quality of sperm, including factors like morphology and motility, is equally important for successful fertilization.

questions.text: Based on the provided semen analysis results, what would be the diagnosis for a young male? The concentration is 5 million per milliliter, motility is 50%, and normal morphology is 4%.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Oligospermia:

  • In the given semen analysis results, the parameters are as follows:
    • Concentration: 5 million/ml (sperm cells per milliliter of semen)
    • Motility: 50% (percentage of sperm cells showing forward movement)
    • Normal Morphology: 4% (percentage of sperm cells with normal shape and structure)
  • Based on these results, the diagnosis is Oligospermia, which refers to a low sperm concentration. In general, a sperm concentration below 15 million/ml is considered low. In this case, the concentration of 5 million/ml falls below the normal range, indicating oligospermia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Teratozoospermia: Teratozoospermia refers to abnormal sperm morphology, where a high percentage of sperm cells have abnormal shape or structure. In the given scenario, the normal morphology is 4%, which is within the normal range. Therefore, teratozoospermia is not the correct diagnosis.

Option C. Asthenozoospermia: Asthenozoospermia refers to reduced sperm motility, where a low percentage of sperm cells show forward movement. In the given scenario, the motility is 50%, which is within the normal range. Therefore, asthenozoospermia is not the correct diagnosis.

OptionD. Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OAT) is a combination of low sperm concentration, reduced sperm motility, and abnormal sperm morphology. While the given semen analysis results indicate low sperm concentration (oligospermia), the motility and morphology are within the normal range. Therefore, oligoasthenoteratozoospermia is not the correct diagnosis.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent action when a patient, who has been taking MALA-N for the past 6 months and has been adhering to the medication, reports having missed periods?

choices.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have delayed period

questions.solution:
Correct Option C-Beta HCG estimation:

  • When a patient on a contraceptive method such as MALA-N (which contains a combination of levonorgestrel and ethinyl estradiol) complains of missed periods, it is important to rule out pregnancy as the cause. The next step in this scenario would be to perform a beta HCG estimation.
  • Beta HCG estimation is a reliable test for determining pregnancy. By performing this test, pregnancy can be confirmed or ruled out as the cause of the missed periods in the patient on MALA-N.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: While a transvaginal ultrasound can provide additional information about the reproductive organs, it may not be the most appropriate initial step when a patient on contraception reports missed periods.

Option B. Reassure her that it's normal to have a delayed period: While it is true that hormonal contraceptives can sometimes cause changes in menstrual bleeding patterns, including missed periods or lighter flow, it is essential to ensure that pregnancy is not the underlying cause.

Option D. Serum FSH and LH: Measurement of serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) levels may be useful in assessing ovarian function and potential hormonal imbalances.

questions.text: Against which serotypes is the HPV nonavalent vaccine effective?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D.

  • This is the correct answer. It includes all the serotypes covered by the HPV nonavalent vaccine, which are serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58. These serotypes are associated with a high risk of developing HPV-related diseases, including cervical cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: These are incorrect options

questions.text: What is the most suitable treatment for a 55-year-old female diagnosed with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium accompanied by atypia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Simple Hysterectomy:

  • Simple hysterectomy: Simple hysterectomy, which involves the removal of the uterus, is considered the ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia. This approach removes the entire uterus, including the atypical cells, eliminating the risk of further progression to endometrial cancer. It is particularly recommended for women who have completed their childbearing and do not desire future fertility.
  • Simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia is a precancerous condition characterized by abnormal cell growth in the endometrial lining of the uterus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: Medroxyprogesterone acetate, a progestin hormone, can be used as a conservative treatment option for women who wish to preserve their uterus and fertility. However, in the case of atypical hyperplasia, the risk of underlying cancerous changes is higher, and conservative treatment may not be sufficient to eliminate the risk completely.

Option C. Levonorgestrel: Levonorgestrel, another progestin hormone, can also be used as a conservative treatment option for simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia. However, as mentioned before, the risk of underlying cancerous changes warrants more definitive treatment options.

Option D. Radiotherapy: It is reserved for cases where the disease has progressed to endometrial cancer or if there is a high risk of recurrence after other treatments.

questions.text: What is the best test to diagnose a vesicovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Cystoscopy:

  • Cystoscopy is a diagnostic procedure that allows direct visualization of the inside of the bladder, urethra, and sometimes the ureters. In the case of a vesicovaginal fistula, cystoscopy is the best diagnostic test.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. 3 swab test: The 3 swab test can also be used to diagnose a vesicovaginal fistula but a cystoscopy is the best test.

Option C. MRI: It is not typically considered the primary diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula. In certain cases, MRI may be used to evaluate complex or recurrent fistulas or to assess the surrounding structures.

Option D. Cystometry: It helps evaluate bladder function and assess urinary symptoms. While cystometry can provide information about bladder function, it is not specifically used to diagnose or assess vesicovaginal fistula.

questions.text: At what gestational age should a pregnant woman with well-controlled blood glucose levels on insulin be delivered if she has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-39 weeks:

  • Delivery at 39 weeks is the appropriate gestational age for women with well-controlled GDM. It allows for adequate fetal maturity while minimizing the risks associated with prolonged pregnancy.
  • At 39 weeks, the benefits of delivery outweigh the risks of continuing the pregnancy, considering the potential for macrosomia (large birth weight) and associated birth complications in infants of mothers with GDM.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. 37 weeks: Delivery at 37 weeks is not the standard recommendation for women with well-controlled GDM. Early delivery at 37 weeks may be considered in cases of poorly controlled GDM or if there are other medical indications such as fetal growth restriction, preeclampsia, or concerns for fetal well-being.

Option C. 38 weeks: Delivery at 38 weeks may be considered in certain cases, but 39 weeks is the preferred gestational age for delivery in women with well-controlled GDM.

Option D. 40 weeks: Delivery at 40 weeks is not the standard recommendation for women with GDM. Prolonging the pregnancy beyond 39 weeks may increase the risk of complications such as macrosomia, shoulder dystocia, and cesarean delivery.

questions.text: What is the recommended dosage of levonorgestrel for emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B-1.5 mg within 72 hours:

  • The recommended dose of levonorgestrel for emergency contraception is 1.5 mg. This single dose should be taken as soon as possible but no later than 72 hours (3 days) after unprotected intercourse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D: These are incorrect options

questions.text: What would be regarded as an absolute contraindication for the insertion of a copper T in a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Previous ectopic pregnancy:

Explanation:

  • Insertion of a copper intrauterine device (IUD), commonly known as Copper T, is generally safe and effective for most women.Women who have had an ectopic pregnancy are at a higher risk of having another ectopic pregnancy in the future. Therefore, inserting an IUD in a woman with a history of ectopic pregnancy can increase the risk of another ectopic pregnancy and its complications, making it an absolute contraindication.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Unmotivated patient: A lack of motivation is not an absolute contraindication for IUD insertion. However, healthcare providers should ensure that the patient understands the benefits, risks, and proper usage of the IUD before insertion.

Option B - Menorrhagia: Menorrhagia, which is heavy menstrual bleeding, is not an absolute contraindication for IUD insertion. In fact, copper IUDs are sometimes used to treat menorrhagia by reducing menstrual bleeding.

Option D - Previous history of abortion: A previous history of abortion, especially if uncomplicated, is not an absolute contraindication for IUD insertion. In fact, IUD insertion can be done after a safe abortion procedure, providing effective contraception for the future.

questions.text: A female comes to Gynecology OPD for pre-conceptual counseling, with 2 prior second trimester abortions. What is the next investigation you will advise?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hysterosalpingography:

  • Hysterosalpingography is a procedure that involves the injection of a contrast dye into the uterus and fallopian tubes to assess their patency. While it can be useful in evaluating the fallopian tubes' blockages or abnormalities, it is the the initial investigation in a case of recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Anatomic abnormalities are responsible for 10–15% of recurrent abortion. The causes may be congenital or acquired. Congenital anomalies may be due to defects in the Müllerian duct fusion or resorption (e.g. unicornuate, bicornuate, septate or double uterus).
    Hysterosalpingography showing bicornuate uterus

​​​​​​​

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pelvic sonography- This option is incorrect

Option C - Endometrial Biopsy: While endometrial biopsy can help identify certain uterine abnormalities or infections, it may not be the initial investigation in a case of recurrent pregnancy loss.

Option D - Karyotyping of the parents: While parental karyotyping may be considered in cases of recurrent pregnancy loss, it is typically not the first investigation performed.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady with submucosal fibroid was undergoing myomectomy. The surgeon was using 1.5% glycine as irrigating fluid for the cavity. During the surgery, the nurse informs that there is a 500ml deficit of the irrigating fluid. What is the next step to be done?

choices.text: Change the fluid to normal saline
Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status
