Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status:

  • While performing a myomectomy fluids may be used to distend the uterus for visualization and manipulation.
  • Fluid can escape into the peritoneal cavity or circulation and careful monitoring of fluids is essential during the procedure.
  • The surgery can be continued in this instance as the deficit is 500ml and careful monitoring will be necessary.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stop the surgery: Stopping the surgery based solely on a 500ml deficit of the irrigating fluid may not be necessary, especially if the patient's vital signs and overall condition are stable.

Option B - Change the fluid to normal saline: While changing the irrigating fluid to normal saline may be an option, it is not the immediate next step in this scenario. In some cases, glycine is preferred for its specific properties, such as maintaining a clear surgical field and minimizing thermal injury.

Option D - Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery: Furosemide is a diuretic medication used to increase urine output. Administering furosemide to address a fluid deficit during surgery may not be necessary or appropriate.

questions.text: A 20 year old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breasts were found to be poorly developed, vagina was present. Ultrasound revealed normal uterus but gonads weren't detected. Further evaluation done showed 46XY karyotype. The most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Swyer's syndrome:

  • Swyer's syndrome is a rare genetic condition characterized by the presence of a 46XY karyotype (typically associated with males) in individuals who have female external genitalia at birth.
  • It is caused by a mutation or deletion in the SRY gene, which is responsible for testicular development. In Swyer's syndrome, the gonads (testes) do not develop properly and are replaced by fibrous tissue, leading to primary amenorrhea and poor breast development. The internal reproductive structures, such as the uterus, may be present and appear normal.

Incorrect Options:


Option A - Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) is a condition in which individuals with a 46XY karyotype have partial or complete insensitivity to androgens (male sex hormones).  

Option B - Turner syndrome: In Turner syndrome, the ovaries are usually underdeveloped or absent. However, the karyotype in Turner syndrome is 45X (45 chromosomes with a missing X chromosome), whereas the scenario describes a 46XY karyotype, ruling out Turner syndrome.
 

Option C - True hermaphrodite: True hermaphrodites can have a variety of karyotypes, including 46XX, 46XY, or mosaic karyotypes. However, in the given scenario, gonads are not detected, which is not consistent with true hermaphroditism

questions.text: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 4mm:

  • In cases of postmenopausal bleeding, transvaginal ultrasonography is commonly used to assess the endometrial thickness. An endometrial thickness of 4mm or greater is often used as the threshold for considering an endometrial biopsy in cases of postmenopausal bleeding. It indicates a thicker endometrial lining that may require further investigation to rule out potential abnormalities.

Incorrect Option:

Option A, C, and D: These statements are incorrect

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Carcinoma vulva:

  • The inguinofemoral group of lymph nodes are the most common lymph nodes in vulval carcinoma.
  • The sentinel lymph node for the vulva is the inguinofemoral group of lymph nodes.
  • SLN biopsy helps determine whether cancer cells have spread to the regional lymph nodes in the groin area. It allows for targeted evaluation of the specific lymph nodes most likely to be affected, enabling accurate staging and guiding subsequent treatment decisions.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Carcinoma vagina: SLN biopsy is less commonly used in Carcinoma vagina compared to other gynecological malignancies. Lymph node involvement in Carcinoma vagina varies, and SLN biopsy may not always be applicable or necessary.

Option C - Carcinoma cervix: SLN biopsy is not routinely performed in Carcinoma cervix. The standard approach for assessing lymph node involvement in Carcinoma cervix is pelvic lymphadenectomy or systemic lymph node sampling.

Option D - Carcinoma endometrium: SLN biopsy is not commonly performed in Carcinoma endometrium. The primary approach for evaluating lymph node involvement in Carcinoma endometrium is a systematic lymphadenectomy, particularly in cases with high-risk features.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones will be secreted in high amounts by the ovarian granulosa cells during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Estrogen:

  • The ovarian granulosa cells, which surround the developing follicle, produce and secrete high amounts of estrogen during the follicular phase.
  • Estrogen helps to thicken the endometrium, promote the growth of the dominant follicle, and inhibit the release of FSH and LH via negative feedback mechanisms.
  • This hormonal activity is crucial for preparing the endometrium for potential implantation and for the maturation of the follicle leading up to ovulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - FSH (Follicle-stimulating hormone): FSH is indeed important during the follicular phase as it stimulates the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles. However, it is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland, not the ovarian granulosa cells.

Option C - LH (Luteinizing hormone): LH is also secreted by the anterior pituitary gland. LH levels surge just before ovulation, triggering the release of the mature egg from the dominant follicle. This surge marks the transition from the follicular phase to the ovulatory phase

Option D - Progesterone: During the follicular phase, progesterone levels are relatively low. Progesterone production is primarily associated with the luteal phase, which occurs after ovulation. During the luteal phase, the corpus luteum forms and secretes progesterone to maintain the endometrium for a potential pregnancy.

questions.text: What would be the appropriate course of action for the management of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III in a 40-year-old female?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Colposcopy with LEEP:

  • Colposcopy helps identify the precise location and extent of the cervical abnormality.
  • LEEP (Loop electrosurgical excision procedure) involves removing the abnormal cervical tissue using a wire loop heated by an electrical current.
  • Colposcopy with LEEP is a commonly used and effective management option for CIN III, as it allows for both diagnosis and treatment of the precancerous lesion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hysterectomy: It may be considered in certain cases, especially when the patient does not desire fertility preservation or when there are other factors warranting hysterectomy.

Option B - Trachelectomy: It is typically performed in women with early-stage cervical cancer who desire fertility preservation. It is not the primary management option for CIN III.

Option C - Conization: Conization is a suitable option for CIN III management when fertility preservation is not a concern or in cases where the lesion is large or extends into the endocervical canal
